characters: VIEW MOVES TO ONE OF THE OLD FISHERMAN
VIEW ON THE TWO FBI AGENTS
VIEW ACROSS THE MEN TO THE STAGE
VIEW ON MICHAEL AND VINCENZO PENTANGELI

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: The Paramount Pictures logo is presented over a simple bl background, as a single trumpet plays the familiar theme a waltz.  White lettering fades in: Mario Puzo's THE GODFATHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause, as the trumpet concludes, and there is additional title: - Part Two -

dialogues.speaker: CORLEONE
dialogues.text: standing impassively, like a young Prince, recently crown King. CLOSE VIEW ON Michael's hand.  ROCCO LAMPONE kisses his h Then it is taken away.  We can SEE only the empty desk an chair of Michael's father, Vito Corleone.  We HEAR, over this, very faintly a funeral dirge played in the distance as THE VIEW MOVES SLOWLY CLOSER to the empty desk and cha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can barely make out the funeral procession passing ove the burnt-brown of a dry river bed.  The figures move slowly, seemingly from out of hundreds of years of the pa The MUSICIANS walking unsteadily on the rocky bed, their instruments harsh and blaring. They are followed by six young peasant men, carrying the crude wooden coffin on their shoulders.  Then the widow, strong large woman, dressed in black, and not accepting t arms of those walking with her. Behind her, not more than twenty relatives, few children paisani continue alone behind the coffin. Suddenly, we HEAR the shots of the lupara, and the musici stop their playing.  The entire procession scatters in od directions along the rocky river bed. The young men struggle with the burden of the heavy coffi throwing it out of balance and nearly crashing to the gro We hear a woman SCREAMING:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've killed young Paolo!  They've killed the boy Paolo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: across the slain body of a fourteen year old boy, lying o the parched ground.  In the distance we see four or five the mourning women, the wind blowing their black dresses veils, running up to the body of the boy.  They begin to wail, and cry out in anguished Sicilian, as the widow, th mother of the murdered boy, holds her child in her arms, fresh blood wetting her strong hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy, eight or nine, with wide, frightened eyes, being pulled quickly by the hand.  This is VITO ANDOLINI, who i to become The Godfather. The VIEW ALTERS revealing that he is being pulled along b his Mother, the Widow, across a field leading to the ornamental gates of a Baronial Estate of some forgotten N At various positions near the gates are men with shotguns or lupara.  The gates are opened; and the Widow and her b are shown before DON FRANCESCO, a man in his sixties.  He wears his trousers with suspenders, and an open white shi sloppily tucked in over his enormous belly.  He wears a h to protect him from the white-hot sun, and proudly displa a gold watch and chain over his vest. He sits in a chair, near a group of his men in the garden listening to the Widow, who stands before him with her on son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Francesco.  You murdered my husband, because he would not bend. And his oldest son Paolo, because he swore revenge.  But Vitone is only nine, and dumb-witted.  He never speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will grow strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child cannot harm you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will be a man, and then he will come for revenge. As she pleads, the Widow moves closer to the Don, until s has practically thrown herself to her knees before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, Don Francesco, spare my only son.  He is all I have.  In the name of the Holy Spirit, I swear he will never be a danger to you... Suddenly, she reaches under her skirt, where she has hidd a kitchen knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I will kill you myself! (she lunges at the Mafia chieftain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitone, go! The boy runs as fast as he can out through the gates.  Th there is a lupara blast.  He turns, and sees his Mother flung a distance of five feet from the short range of the terrible blast of the shotgun.  Then he sees the men turn their attention to him.  One fires at him; but the boy is quick, and disappears into a grove of olive trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men roam the deserted streets of Corleone, carrying lupare.  Every so often, they stop, and one shouts in a loud, almost singsong voice, like a fish peddler.  Their names are MOSCA and STROLLO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Friend promises misery to anyone who harbors the boy Vito Andolini. (he turns and shouts in the other direction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Friend promises misery to anyone who harbors the boy Vito Andolini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A family quietly eats their dinner.  The father is the lo policeman, as indicated by his uniform jacket and gun, hanging nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian, O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Friend will be hard with any family who gives help to Vito Andolini. One of the children looks up, about to speak.  But the father sternly indicates that nothing must be said.  They on with their dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men continue walking up and throughout the streets, f in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...misery to any family who harbors the boy, Vito...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four little girls watch with wide eyes as their mother an father bind Vito tightly in swaddled cloth, and then lift him up to the side of a mule; counter-balancing a heavy l of firewood.  The father looks at the boy's almost stoica calm little face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito...We pray for you. He pulls the fabric over the boy's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Andolini...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Friend promises misery to any family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men continue on their night-walk, up to the plaza of church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who harbors the boy Vitone Andolini. The figure of a single man on a mule passes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let no one give help to the boy Vito Andolini... The man on the mule makes his way out of the village and disappears into the distance. We begin to hear, very quietly, the Waltz repeated once a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: huddled in blankets, on the deck of the ship in Steerage. He does not say a word.  The Waltz grows louder as the VI ALTERS, revealing the hundreds of immigrant families hudd together with all their earthly possessions on their way America. Then, suddenly, the Waltz stops.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEW YORK HARBOR
dialogues.text: SILENCE.  We glide past the Statue of Liberty. VIEW on the IMMIGRANTS standing on shipboard silently; looking.  Vito is standing with them, his eyes wide. CAMERA MOVES IN on the statue, then MOVING PAST, on to th beautiful buildings of Ellis Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tugboat pulls a barge brimming with immigrants into the Ellis Island harbor.  Uniformed officials of the Immigrat Service load them up toward the main building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hundreds of immigrant families sit on rows of benches the great hall.  Various painted lines lead to the steps processing rooms above. There is the babble of many interviews going on simultaneously, uncertainly, in different languages. Vito is bundled in an old coat, with a large tag pinned o it: "Vitone Andolini -- Corleone, Sicilia." He stands, moves up in the line, when several other immig boys, older than he, rush up an push him back in the line Weak from the trip, he falls to the floor.  The boys laug derisive in a language he cannot understand.  He struggle to his feet, lifting his makeshift bags; staring at them an icy hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three or four interviews are crowded into the small room; they are conducted in English.  From the expression on Vito's face, and from the fragmented of the English, we realize that he doesn't understand a word of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name? The man waits, impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name? Vito doesn't answer.  The Official pulls the tag pinned o his coat and copies to down on his form, using a typewrit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking as he types)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito...Corleone.  Step up, over there. He hands the form to another official. CLOSE VIEW on the form.  The name has been entered as Vit Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito is stripped to the waist, as other immigrants wait. The DOCTOR is just finishing his examination.  He shakes head, and then writes on the medical form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you understand me? Vito stares blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand?  Smallpox.  Smallpox. He doesn't understand.  The doctor turns to the Immigrati Official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quarantine...six months.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERGROUND PASSAGEWAY
dialogues.text: Officials move a group of immigrant men, including Vito, the quarantine section of the Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The official stops at each doorway, and reads off a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salvatore Ormenta. The man moves into the room, and the group proceeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito Corleone. No one responds.  The guard moves to the boy, reads his n name tag.  And then, not unkindly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's you. He opens the door, and Vito enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VIEW slowly begins to pull back, revealing this to be the view from inside the quarantine cell, where Vito stan on his bench, looking out to the statue through the barre window. Then he turns, and sits in the corner.  He is silent for long time. Then, in a sweet, pure voice, he sings to himself in Sici

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nine year old boy, dressed immaculately in white, with large white silk bow tied to his shoulder, moving slowly down the aisle of the church with a group of other childr dressed in white.  He has dark black hair, and his face i unmistakably similar to young Vito's.  He moves slowly, h hands clasped around a golden missal.  We HEAR only the p voice of Vito in Sicilian, his sad song reaching out from the past, as ANTHONY CORLEONE, his Grandson, moves on the way to his First Holy Communion more than fifty years lat

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: The little children move in procession down to the Altar, where the PRIEST raises the Host, and performs the Commun Mass in Latin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecce Agnus Dei, ecce qui tollit peccata mundi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and Altar boys, as he moves along the row of kneeling children, blessing them, and administering their first Communion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the innocent faces receive the Host; finally, the Prie comes to Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corpus Christi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lawns of this great estate on the shore of Lake Tahoe are covered with guests of a wonderful party to honor the First Holy Communion of Anthony Corleone, the son of Mr. Mrs. Michael Corleone.  A full dance orchestra plays musi of the times on a pavilion bandstand built especially for the occasion.  Speedboats roar through the water, pulling youthful waterskiers; and the pool and private harbor are filled with laughing, swimming guests.  It is Fall of 195

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Anthony, in his Communion suit sits alone at the table, looking like a lonely young Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile, Anthony.  Smile. He does, and a flash goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, one with the whole family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Corleone can't right now... KAY CORLEONE enters from the side, leading her four year daughter, MARY, and MAMA CORLEONE to pose with Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but we'll get one with the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All together now, c'mon, Anthony... CHEESE and (flash)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She smiles as she leaves the photographer, and then lets a weary sigh to Mama, as she touches the slightly protrud belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it'll show in the picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months never shows.  Two months look like you had a big lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Corleone. A slender, aristocratic WOMAN in her late forties is wavi to KAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Corleone.  I'm Fran Barrett, our place is just down the lake.  This is my husband, Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy you could come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is transformed.  We've been watching workmen come and go all summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Mr. Corleone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A business meeting ran late...but he promised he wouldn't be long. Kay puts her arm around little Anthony's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our son Anthony Vito Corleone.  Today he made his First Holy Communion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A confusion of cars; arriving and parking.  The squad of parking attendants are supplemented by a whole team of th local Police, working as high-class parking valets. A very beautiful, statuesque woman, though slightly drunk DEANNA DUNN, slams the door of a powder blue Mercedes and hurries barefoot through the great stone gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not shut my mouth, and keep your Goddamn hands off of me! She is followed by a harried, FREDDIE CORLEONE, dressed w flash in the Hollywood style, and carrying her shoes in h hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey!  Wait a minute; let's go for a drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had a drive; besides, I want to see my brother-in-law Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to get her to put her shoes on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I don't want him to see you. Deanna pauses reflectively a moment, allowing Fredo to ge her shoes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What beats me, is how you guys could be brothers.  You musta been your Mother's rotten egg. She kicks off the shoes, giggling, and runs toward a wait

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting a glass of champagne)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, young man...thank you, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but aren't you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you saw me in the movies, Good Humor man, and yes, I had more off than my shoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Freddie honey.  Come dance with me. She extends her hand to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Michael's got a lot of nice people here.  Friends of Kay's. He'll never forgive me if you ruin his party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to see you cringe in front of him.  How come you're so scared of your own kid brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the head of the family. Disgusted, she turns around, and heads toward the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't follow me!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Rushing through the tables, waving an arm jangling with g jewelry, and carrying several gift-wrapped packages, is a hardened and aging CONNIE CORLEONE.  She is followed by a blond, and wrinkled-handsome escort named MERLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama...Mama!  Here I am! She throws her arms around her Mother, who returns the affection somewhat reproachfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanzia.  We expected you last week; we sent the car to pick you up at the airport last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, it was chaos; but anyway, here I am one week late. (lifting a shiny green package out of Merle's arms)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for my Mama.  You remember Merle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not giving him a chance to greet her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, they asked for you all week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got surprises for everybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at the wrapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bought at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing about)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is swell.  Where's Michael? I've got things to get straight with him and I can't wait on line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go see your children first, and then you wait to see your brother like everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A porch-like foyer of the boathouse, where a group of fiv or six men wait, some nervously.  Some sit, and some pace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on one of these men, FRANKIE PENTANGELI, approaching his sixties, with gray hair (the little of it left).  He's a scruffy, this morning's shave of his white beard is not perfect, and he seems tired.  He is accompanied by an associate-bodyguard, WILLY CICCI; thin and dark, and also dressed up for the occasion.  Frankie tries to get the attention of one of the waiters; a college-groomed young in white sports jacket and black bow-tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, kid!  You got any red wine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering the tray)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only champagne and cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it... Finally, he sees someone he recognizes, Fredo, and shouts out in a husky voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo!  Sonuvabitch.  You look great. Fredo squints in his direction; finally recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?  Pentangeli?  Frankie "Five-Angels"...thought you were never coming West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectionately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta check up on my boys.  Hey, what's with the food?  Some kid in a white jacket brings me a ritz cracker with some chopped liver. 'Canapes,' he says.  I say, 'Can a peas, my ass, that's a ritz cracker with chopped liver.' Go get me a salami sandwich and a glass of wine or I'll send you and your white jacket to the dry cleaners! They get a good laugh at this fresh breath of New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Frankie, it's good to see you. Reminds me of old times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Willy Cicci, don't you, Freddie?  We was all together with the old man Clemenza in Brooklyn... before...uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were all upset about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm here to talk to your brother about.  What's with him, I got to get a letter of introduction to have a 'sitdown'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing his arm around him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra wears white summer sportcoats and black tux slacks as they play a tango behind monogrammed music stan A professional dance team, probably imported from Vegas, dance the tango for the excited guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large and very beautiful room overlooking the lake.  It dominated by an enormous bar, behind which stands ALBERT NERI, discreetly in the background. MICHAEL CORLEONE sits on a large sofa, his back to us. Standing to one side is a tired and somewhat uneasy TOM HAGEN.  Standing before Michael is SANDRA CORLEONE, Sonny widow; her daughter, one of the twins, FRANCESCA CORLEONE and a handsome young man of twenty, GARDNER SHAW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, this is Gardner Shaw. Francesca and he have been seeing each other for six months now. Gardner, this is Francie's Uncle Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard a lot about you, Mr. Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.  Francie. The couple sit themselves on the sofa opposite Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They would like to set an engagement date, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them speak for themselves. VIEW ON MICHAEL, calm, thoughtful.  One can tell that he special affection for his niece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We love each other, Uncle Michael. And, we want to be married.  I came to ask for your blessing. There is a loud KNOCKING on the door; then Fredo's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mike...guess who's here? Neri goes to answer it, cracks the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Freddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mike Frankie 'Five-Angels' is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now... Neri closes the door, and Michael looks at the nervous yo man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is my oldest brother's daughter.  He died many years ago, and ever since I've felt much more of a father than an uncle.  I love her very much.  I'm pleased and impressed that you had the thought to come to me before going on with your plans.  It shows me that you're a considerate man, and will be good to her.  What are you studying in college?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My major is Fine Arts, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will Fine Arts support your new wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's embarrassing to say, sir, but I'm a major stockholder in the family corporation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never be embarrassed by your wealth. This recent contempt for money is still another trick of the rich to keep the poor without it. (warmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I give you my blessing. Let's set the wedding soon...it will be my pleasure to give the bride away. They all smile, and rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and take a few courses in Business Administration just to be on the safe side! They laugh; Michael moves toward them.  Francesca throws arms around him, and kisses her favorite uncle.  The flus young man shakes his hand heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Uncle Michael. They all take their leave; Michael turns to Hagen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make her dowry impressive.  He comes from a family who still thinks an Italian bride goes barefoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca and Gardner are greeted by her twin sister and their young friends, who squeal and embrace at the good n Someone throws someone in the pool, and life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca kisses her Aunt Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Michael is the greatest man ever! VIEW on Kay - happy for her niece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael sits in the darkened boathouse.  Tom Hagen paces. Michael is looking at photographs.  Neri stands over him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: studying the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Fred Vincent.  He owns a small pizza parlor in Buffalo...

dialogues.speaker: THE PICTURES
dialogues.text: Snapshots of a middle-aged man, handsome, Italian.  There something familiar about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...American wife and two small kids. We traced him and found that he's in the country illegally, from Sicily... Michael looks at another picture.  The same man.  Only younger, and dressed in Sicilian shepherd's clothing.  We remember him as FABRIZZIO...Michael's traitorous bodyguar in Sicily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...came over around 1956.  Sponsored by the Barzini Family. Michael puts the pictures down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him.  Fabrizzio. (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revenge is a dish that tastes best when it's cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you want me to handle it? Michael glances at Hagen, who has been waiting in the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later.  Tom? Hagen brings him a folder; then, as Michael glances throu it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've cleared it through the Senator's chief aide, a man named Turnbull.  Turnbull's a heavy gambler, and into us for over a hundred grand, so I figure his information is reliable. Neri moves to the bar, to prepare Michael a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator can be set up; but he thinks of himself as a clean politician.  So it's got to be on terms he can live with: campaign contribution, donation to a charitable cause that he controls, things like that.  If he gets even the inkling that you think you're buying him, he'll freeze up. Nevada's a funny state, they like things both ways here... All right. Turnbull says the Senator will be here at two-thirty, and he's been primed.  He knows you'll want to meet with him alone, and he knows it's about the Tropicana's license. At any rate, he expects to be introduced around to some of the influential people here today, and generally treated as an ordinary guest.  Just go light on him, Mikey, sometimes the biggest crooks don't like to think of themselves as crooks... Michael glances at Hagen, as though that last remark was unnecessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry; of course, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-thirty.  That gives me time to see my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie's outside. Michael doesn't want to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised; she said it was urgent. Michael nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Apologize to Pentangeli. Neri opens the door; Hagen exits, and Connie steps in impatiently, followed by Merle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I would see my sister, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this concerns me too. (taking a cigarette from the dispenser)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't, do you? Connie steps forward, kisses Michael on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, honey?  You've met Merle, haven't you.  He was with me in Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Europe next week.  I want to get passage booked on the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you come to me?  Why don't you go to a travel agent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to get married first. Michael is silent.  Then he rises, and moves to the windo overlooking the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ink on your divorce isn't dry. Your children see you on weekends; your oldest boy, Michael Francis... was in some trouble with the Reno police over some petty theft that you don't even know about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fly around the world with lazy young men who don't have any love for you, and use you like a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not my father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you come to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I need MONEY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie, I want to be reasonable with you.  You have a house here, with us.  You can live here with your kids...and you won't be deprived of anything.  I don't know much about Merle; I don't know what he does for a living; what he lives on.  Why don't you tell him marriage is really out of the question; and that you can't see him any more. He'll understand.  But if you disobey me, and marry this pimp...it would disappoint me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my father's money; and I'm entitled to what I need.  Where is Tom Hagen? She turns angrily, leaving Michael standing face to face with Merle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then out. Merle puts out his cigarette and leaves, quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra has struck up a "Paul Jones," where two concentric circles of young people march in opposite directions, until the music stops.  Then they take whomev is opposite them as their new dance partner.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE HARBOR AREA
dialogues.text: Francesca and her twin, Gardner and their elite young friends roar out of the private harbor, to get up on the water skis.  We notice ROCCO LAMPONE, move along a path leading to a separate and more private boathouse.  A smal covered craft approaches, ties off, and a group of three step on to the pathway, shake hands with Lampone - and follow him to the large boathouse where Michael conducts business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pentangeli has led Mama up to the dance floor, and is hav some difficulty with the orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe that out of thirty professional musicians, not one of you is Italian! (as the musicians laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, give us a tarantella. He waves his hands, conducting, and singing.  The piano starts a vamp, the drums uncertainly join in.  A clarinet starts to play "Pop Goes the Weasel," and soon the rest o the orchestra is playing that.  They look to Pentangeli f approval.  Disgusted, he goes back to his table, eating a handful of canapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco ushers an older Italian, bundled up against the col and wet of his boatride, to Michael. The man shows respect to Michael, who quickly indicates t Neri should get him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco, his friends must be hungry. See what you can do, but I'd like to keep them away from the guests. The older man, JOHNNY 'BLUE BOY' OLA, gestures to his bodyguards, and they follow Lampone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my lawyer, Tom Hagen. Johnny Ola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I remember Tom from the old days. Tom shakes hands with Ola, remembering him, and his importance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom isn't going to sit in with us, Johnny.  He only handles specific areas of the family business.  Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mikey. He gathers up some of his papers, as the three men remain silent, waiting for him to go before they talk.  It's cle Tom doesn't want to be excluded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need anything, just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell Rocco I'm waiting. Hagen nods and leaves.  As soon as the door closes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just left our friend in Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is his health?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do; anything I can send?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He appreciates your concern, Michael, and your respect. There's a KNOCK on the door; a moment, and then Rocco quietly enters and takes his place without disturbing the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hotel's registered owners are one Jacob Lawrence, and Sidney Barclay, both Beverly Hills attorneys.  In reality it's split between the Old Lakeville Road Group from Cleveland, and our friend in Miami.  He takes care of others outside the country, you know who I mean.  Meyer Klingman runs the store, and does all right, but I've been instructed to tell you, that if you move him out, our friend in Miami will go along with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very kind, tell him it's appreciated.  I'm sure it will be profitable all the way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always makes money for his partners.  One by one, our old friends are gone.  Death, natural or not, prison, deported.  Our friend in Miami is the only one left, because he always made money for his partners. The door opens suddenly, and standing there in his white Communion suit, is Michael's boy Anthony.  A moment later Kay appears, and takes the boy's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, Daddy's busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my boy, and my wife.  Mr. John Ola of Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Michael.  Senator Geary's here, and Mr. and Mrs. Barrett wanted to thank you before they left.  Won't you join us, Mr. Ola?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ola's just leaving, Kay. Please tell the Senator I won't be a minute. Pause; she stands there a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay closes the door.  It seems as though Michael has viol some sort of promise to her by having this man here today She looks up toward the first boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The covered launch, and Ola's three bodyguards, eating wh they wait.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Anthony runs away from her, heading toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony! (she runs after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, where are you going? Moodily, the boy stops, turns, and walks back to his tabl of honor without answering her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra has taken its break; now two couples in for dress are performing the Quartet from Rigoletto.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN
dialogues.text: sitting by himself, a little down, having a drink.  He's waiting for Michael to re-summon him.  SANDRA, Sonny's widow, sits opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Mama, putting the baby to sleep.  Francesca's very happy. Michael was kind to her.  She idolizes him. (pause; she looks at a despondent Hagen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are all out in the speedboat.  I'm going to my house. Sandra gets up, still an attractive woman, and walks alon to the back path that leads to her home on the estate.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE PAVILION
dialogues.text: The returned orchestra strikes a big, show-biz chord, intended to command the guests' attention. The orchestra LEADER raises his hands for silence, and ma an announcement over the P.A. system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, a most distinguished guest would like to say a few words: Senator and Mrs. Pat Geary of the state of Nevada! A big hand, as the smiling SENATOR introduces his WIFE by holding her arm up to the crowd, and then proceeds alone the bandstand.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Michael stands with Kay and Mrs. Geary.  The Senator's presence seems to be a statement of political and social status. A little distance away, his beautiful son Anthony sits quietly, in an unmistakably morose mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the applause and whistles echoing in the distance Sandra stands in her bedroom, looking at the door.  We SE photograph of SONNY, and also one of their wedding. A moment goes by, and then Tom Hagen enters, closing the door behind him. We begin to HEAR Senator Geary's amplified voice resoundi over the lake.  Hagen moves to Sandra.  She takes him in arms, comforting, holding his head against her full breas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't want my help any more. He doesn't need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know that's true, he never said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can feel it in the way he talks to me. He moves to the dresser; pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now when Johnny Ola showed up, he asked me to leave them alone. Ola is Hyman Roth's Sicilian contact.  I was on the inside of ten, twenty meetings with him.  But today Mike asked me to leave, like an outsider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to him.  Tell him how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as though he blames me for the ground the family lost when I was Consigliere to Sonny. Sandra pulls Hagen to her, and kisses him passionately on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Michael, I want to help him, be close to him.  I don't want to end up a third string lawyer making property settlements for the hotels. Sandra knows he needs her.  Slowly she begins to undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a little time now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...my thanks, and the thanks of the young people of the State of Nevada, for this most impressive endowment... (he holds a check in his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...made to the University in the name of Anthony Vito Corleone. Thank you, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Corleone. Applause.  Senator Geary returns the microphone to the Maestro who adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, the Nevada Boys' Choir have prepared a special thank you for Mr. Michael Corleone. He turns to a small Choir Master, who leads the Boys' Cho in a choral arrangement of "MR. WONDERFUL."

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON SENATOR GEARY
dialogues.text: shaking hands with Michael, as Press Photographers snap pictures, showing the check; showing a special award of Gratitude from the State; Mrs. Corleone and Mrs. Geary; a together; Michael and his son; Senator Geary and Michael' son; and on and on.  In the midst of this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can we meet alone? Michael indicates the boathouse a distance away, where Ne seems to be waiting for them.  Then Michael leans to Rocc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find Hagen. Rocco sets off; as more pictures are taken, and the:

dialogues.speaker: BOYS' CHOIR
dialogues.text: sings its lovely arrangement of "Mr. Wonderful."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, the Senator, Neri and Rocco make a group in the dark, large room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was very kind of you to come to my home on this occasion, Senator. My wife has been very concerned with making a good impression on the people who are our neighbors, and your appearance here has made her very happy.  If I can ever perform a service for you, you only have to ask. The door opens, and Hagen sheepishly makes his way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lawyer, Tom Hagen.  He arranged this all through your man Turnbull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we would meet alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust these men with my life. They are my right arms; I cannot insult them by sending them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking out some medication)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some water. He addresses that to Neri, who resentfully goes to fetch Senator a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Corleone.  I'm going to be very frank with you.  Maybe more frank than any man in my position has ever spoken to you before. Michael nods, indicating that he should do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corleone family controls two major hotels in Vegas; one in Reno. The licenses were grandfathered in, so you had no difficulties with the Gaming Commission.  But I have the idea from sources... (takes the water from Neri and swallows his pills)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that you're planning to move in on the Tropicana.  In another week or so you'll move Klingman out, which leaves you with only one technicality.  The license, which is now in Klingman's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turnbull is a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's forget the bullshit, I don't want to stay here any longer than I have to.  You can have the license for two hundred and fifty thousand in cash, plus a monthly fee equal to five percent of the gross... Michael is taken aback; he looks at Hagen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of all three Corleone hotels. Hagen is frustrated; all his information was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Geary, I speak to you as a businessman who has made a large investment in your state.  I have made that state my home; plan to raise my children here.  The license fee from the Gambling Commission costs one thousand dollars; why would I ever consider paying more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to squeeze you, Corleone, because I don't like you; I don't like the kind of man you are.  I despise your masquerade, and the dishonest way you pose yourself and your fucking family.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN
dialogues.text: glances at Michael.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: makes no outward reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all part of the same hypocrisy, Senator.  But never think it applies to my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then let me say you'll pay me because it's in your interests to pay me.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON GEARY
dialogues.text: rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll expect your answer, with payment, by tomorrow morning.  Only don't contact me...from now on, deal only through Turnbull. He is almost out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator... (cold and calm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you can have my answer now if you'd like. Geary turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My offer is this.  Nothing...not even the thousand dollars for the Gaming Commission, which I'd appreciate if you would put up personally. Geary returns Michael's hard look; then laughs and leaves Slowly Michael turns to Hagen.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN
dialogues.text: embarrassed at being so off the mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Tom, we'll talk later.  Tell Frankie Pentangeli I'd like him to have dinner at my family table before we do business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the light has faltered, and the young waiters have pu up the night lights.  The tables are all properly set for dinner, with candles on each one. The orchestra is playing quiet, unobtrusive dinner music, and many of the guests have begun to help themselves to t impressive buffet, under a party tent.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Michael sits at a large table with Kay, his son Anthony, Mama, Hagen and TERESA, Connie and Merle' Fredo and Deann and Frankie Pentangeli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cent' Anne. This, the table of honor, all raise their glasses and rep the toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's 'cent' Anne?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred years...it's a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means we should all live happily for one hundred years.  The family. If my Father were alive, it'd be true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merle, have you met my sister-in- law Deanna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a pleasure, Merle. (shaking hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those two are perfect for each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, in all respect, I didn't come three thousand miles for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do we talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner. By now, the conversation has become exclusively Sicilian, with Merle and Deanna, looking from side to side like in tennis match.  Finally, Kay, to be polite:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, you were talking to Mr. Pentangeli?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is "Five-Angels."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the kid and me talked Sicilian. A one-way conversation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pentangeli is angry; but because it is Michael he is talk to, he keeps his voice low and represses his desire to sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Pete Clemenza died of a heart attack, but the Rosato Brothers gave it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were all heartbroken at the news; but that wasn't cause to start a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now it's my family in Brooklyn; and I wanna keep up Clemenza's loyalty to you.  But how can I run my family with you challenging my every move?  You're too far from the street, Mike, the only way to reason with the Rosato Brothers is to whack 'em and whack 'em fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were unfair with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemenza promised Rosato three territories in the Bronx after he died, and then you took over and welched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemenza promised them nothing, he hated the sonsuvbitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They feel cheated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, you're sitting up here in the Sierra Mountains with champagne cocktails making judgment on the way I run my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly in Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family still carries the name Corleone, and you will run it like a Corleone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while I feed my family in New York, you put the knife in my back in Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie, you're a good old man, and you've been loyal to my Father for years...so I hope you can explain what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rosatos are running crazy; taking hostages, spitting in my face, because they're backed by the Jew in Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  That's why I want you to be fair with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be fair with animals? They recruit niggers and spicks; they do violence in their own Grandmother's neighborhoods.  And everything is dope and whores; the gambling is left to last.  Let me run my family without you on my back.  I want them taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  There are things that I have planned with Hyman Roth.  I don't want them disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give your loyalty to a Jew over your own blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie, you know my father respected Roth, did business with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did business...but he never trusted him. Pentangeli takes his hat, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man had too much vino rosso, or he'd never talk openly that way.  Let him go back to New York; I've already made my plans. (he checks his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late; I've spent so little time at the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the sun has fallen and the lawns of the Corleone estate are lit by moonlight.  Beautifully dressed couples dance as the orchestra plays a foxtrot of the late fiftie

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Deanna has been dancing with Fredo; she has gotten drunk it teasing her husband by flirting with other men on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta dance...whatsa matter with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dancing is alright; you're falling on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsamatter, you don't want me to dance with him 'cause he's a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deanna, I'm going to belt you right in the mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These Eye-ties are really crazy when it comes to their wives. By now guests are starting to notice the disturbance; Michael is with Kay, and some friends; Rocco catches his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, never marry a WOP, they treat their wives like shit. VIEW on Kay, listening, embarrassed by her flashy sister- law.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON FREDO AND DEANNA
dialogues.text: Rocco passes by Fredo and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie, Mike says take care of it, or I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a friend of your brother! Without another word, Rocco grabs firm hold of her and whisks her out of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Shuffle off to Buffa... Shuffle off to Buffa... Shuffle off to Buffalooooo..." Freddie mops his forehead, and moves to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mike, what can I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, just go take care of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large group of Tahoe teenagers join the Corleone youngs sitting around a large fire out by the harbor.  Gardner a Francie, sitting arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Anthony, in his white suit, sitting alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up, and is signaled over to the gate by a policeman carrying a torch flashlight. Connie and Merle enter; Merle tips the cop, and the cab drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay and Michael dancing in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping inside me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it feel like a boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Michael, it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about some of the people I had to see today.  It was bad timing... but it couldn't be helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It made me think of what you told me once.  In five years, the Corleone family will be completely legitimate.  That was seven years ago. He has no answer for her; except that he loves and values her, and holds her tight, as they dance amid their guests all dressed elegantly for the social event of the season. The VIEW LOOSENS to show the entire, night-lit party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Cadillac limousine waits for some people inside the tac Las Vegas marriage mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some quiet, informally dressed couples wait in the rear o the chapel; some talking, others sitting nervously. A single organ plays some standard wedding music. The VIEW PANS up to the altar, where Connie and Merle, in the same clothing they wore to the Tahoe party, are being married by a Justice of the Peace. The Justice goes through the bored, simple ceremony, and begin to HEAR an echo of the waltz Connie danced with her father, when she was married all those years ago in Long Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark car pulls up to the glitter of the neon facade. Albert Neri, alone, leaves it to the parking valets, and moves quickly through the automatic doors, into the main casino.  We still hear the CORLEONE WALTZ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert Neri enters the room; glances around a moment, and then heads toward the crap table, where a short, middle-a man, KLINGMAN, stands by the pit boss.  Several security guards of the casino, are at their posts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Klingman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can we talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I represent the interests of the Corleone family.  We make the invitation to you to tie up your affairs and be out of the hotel by Monday morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think you're talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you were Klingman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't come in here, talk to an owner in Las Vegas like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed my point; you are no longer an owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my hotel. Neri stands in front of him, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, get him out of here. Quickly, Neri moves toward Klingman, and slaps him hard several times in the face, knocking off his glasses... Re faced, Klingman gets down on his knees to pick them up on again.  Glasses on, he looks to his guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand, motionless.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KLINGMAN
dialogues.text: Humiliated, Klingman moves across the casino floor, past few interested gamblers, and his own people.  Neri slowly follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A typical, Lido de Paris type of show is in rehearsal, as Klingman backs into the showroom.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: Neri keeps coming.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KLINGMAN
dialogues.text: realizes that no one will help him.  He finally capitulat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right!  All right, I'll be out. Neri keeps moving, then heads past the terrified man, sit down at a table, and looks up at the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the staring performers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neon lights that spell out "FRED'S PIZZERIA" go out; after a moment a man in an overcoat steps out, and turns lock the door of his restaurant.  The Corleone Waltz continues over this.  He turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED VINCENT, whom we remember as the Sicilian Fabrizzio. He moves toward his parked car.  Gets in.

dialogues.speaker: MED. LONG VIEW
dialogues.text: The starter turns, and the automobile blows in a great explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waltz continues over the VIEW of the empty, but still illuminated pavilion.  There is the debris of the great party spread over the grounds, which a silent crew of workmen are at work cleaning up,

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Michael walks alone, followed by two of the family dogs, Irish Setters. He walks to the water line, and looks out across the lake He picks up a stick, and throws it for the dogs; who go scampering after it. We notice that a respectful distance away, there are bodyguards watching every move he makes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking across the lake.  There is much on his mind.  The SOUND of the waltz, begins to segue into the echoed music and laughter of an old Italian Music Hall from the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VITO CORLEONE is a shy young man of 23, holding his hat i his hand, being led down the crowded aisle of this Italia Vaudeville theatre by an energetic and fulfilled GENCO ABBANDANDO, his friend in America.  This entire sequence played in Sicilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you've got to see her!

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE STAGE
dialogues.text: A tattered melodrama is in progress in Neapolitan.  The s are two-dimensional, and flap whenever there's an entranc or exit. The hero, PEPPINO, is weeping as he sings about how he's left his Mother in Italy, while he is in this new country America.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: All poor, Italo-Americans.  Genco finds a few seats, and leads Vito to them, stepping on a few shoes in the proces They have barely come to their seats, when an excited Gen nudges Vito, and points to the stage.  People shout that they should sit down.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE STAGE
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door, and a young girl enters, delivering a letter to Peppino in his tenement in America The girl is pretty; and obviously the object of Genco's affection.  The letter brings bad news.  Peppino's Mother dead.  He weeps, and sings the final song, which most of audience knows: SENZA MAMMA.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Genco is enthralled with the young actress.  The people i the audience are singing along with Peppino.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE STAGE
dialogues.text: The actress, object of Genco's affection, makes a dramati exit.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Genco pulls on Vito's jacket, indicating that now that hi love is offstage, they should leave.  Vito rises with him and they make their way all the way down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genco hurrying down the backstage corridor, hoping to cat a glimpse of the actress.  He is followed by Vito.  Sudde Genco stops short.

dialogues.speaker: GENCO'S VIEW
dialogues.text: A heavy-set, fierce looking Italian wearing an expensive light-colored suit and a cream colored fedora.  This is FANUCCI.  He is discussing a business matter with the theatre IMPRESARIO; a large, strong looking man, who is sweating nonetheless.  He doesn't seem to be giving in to Fanucci.  He holds a locked strongbox.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON VITO
dialogues.text: watching.  The two men argue in Italian.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The young ACTRESS crosses into the area, unaware of the difficulties.  The impresario sees her, and frightened, motions that she should keep away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla! But Fanucci grabs her easily by her slender wrist, and wi lightning speed, produces a knife which he holds against cheek.  The impresario wrings his hands in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...please, not my daughter. Whereupon he begins to unlock the box which holds the receipts for the night's box-office.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON GENCO AND VITO
dialogues.text: hiding, watching.  At first, Genco is enraged, as though would rush up to help his enamorata.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Hand. Then he backs away.  Vito looks at him shocked and disappointed in this cowardly behavior.  Genco shakes his head, and points, as though to say that where Fanucci is concerned, there is nothing to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (whispered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON FANUCCI
dialogues.text: has released the girl.  Her father pulls her away from hi and slaps her for no reason; then he pays Fanucci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you protested, it will cost a hundred more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genco and Vito; Genco leans against the wall, breathlessl as though he's had a near escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you are thinking, Vitone, but you don't understand yet how things are.  Fanucci is of the Black Hand.  Everyone in the neighborhood pays him, even my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an Italian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pig of a Neaponitan. (spits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Why does he bother other Italians?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he knows them; he knows they have no one to protect them. Vitone?  What do you think of my angel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, she is beautiful.  For me, there is only my wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  That's why I brought you with me! Genco embraces his good friend, and they laughingly walk down the alley. The stage door opens, and Fanucci exits, a sinister figur in white, moving down the alley just in front of them, in the night. The two friends hold their breath, until he disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito moves through the street, carrying groceries that he to deliver. It is cold, and so vendors are huddled around fires they have lit in old cans and drums. He turns up an alleyway, and then stops.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW UP THE ALLEY
dialogues.text: With great strength, Fanucci lifts one of them up into th air and throws him down hard to the concrete; but another holding onto his back, manages to produce a switchblade knife and awkwardly reaching around from behind the movin man, slits Fanucci's throat from one side to the other. Fanucci groans like some great hurt animal.  Blood pours from the deep, smile-like slit in his throat. He throws the young man off his back.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON VITO
dialogues.text: stepping back in the alley.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON FANUCCI
dialogues.text: He takes off his white fedora, and runs down the alley toward Vito, catching the flowing blood in his hat. The young attackers scurry off in various directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny shop featuring imported food: trays of cured meats prosciutto, copagole, mortadella lies on the counter cove with netting to keep away the thousands of flies. Olive oil is sold in bulk, as well as wine, cheese and ba Genco works here for his father, and is busy slicing pape thin prosciutto for a customer, by hand.  Vito works in t back as a stock clerk. Finished with his customer, Genco moves to his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you can't guess what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guys from Ninth Avenue jumped Fanucci today; slit his throat from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't know.  Is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.  Those guys aren't murderers. They wanted to scare him, that's all.  Make him look bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Sicily, when you attack a man, you had better finish him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish they had.  He takes fifty dollars a week from my father's cash drawer.  But you can't kill a man like Fanucci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's what we say... "connected"... You wait, see what happens to those guys from Ninth Avenue. A customer enters; and Genco moves away to serve him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: recalling what he had seen and thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man, one of those who had tried to kill Fanucci, runs down an alleyway, breathlessly.  Then he stops, and looks behind himself.  Whoever was following him is gone. He turns and walks ahead.  Then the mammoth, white-suited figure of Fanucci leaps down before him from the fire-esc He grins at the young man, and then raises his neck, show the gruesome wound that marks his throat. He takes out his pistol and fires point-blank at his atta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very small, railroad type flat where Vito lives with new family. It is late at night, and he is exhausted. He returns home; where his young wife, CARMELLA, goes through the silent ritual of preparing a simple meal for He sits and eats quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito and Carmella enter the darkened bedroom, and approac metal crib.  Vito reaches down and takes the small hand o the baby between his thick peasant fingers.  Carmella wai a respectful distance behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shop bell RINGS; SINGER ABBANDANDO turns to see a smiling Fanucci tipping his hat, like an old customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno. Immediately, Vito turns back to his work, and Signor Abbandando moves to Fanucci with a sigh. Vito notices the two men talking quietly at one side of t store, while he goes about his work.  Genco works his way closer to his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you.  The one who cut him was found in an alley.  And the family of the others paid Fanucci all their savings to make him forswear his vengeance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he agreed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took the money.  Now he wants double from everybody in the neighborhood, including Papa. Vito watches the heated, but inevitable transaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real mafioso doesn't sell his vengeance.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Signor Abbandando seems to be arguing with Fanucci, and every so often they turn and relate to where Vito is work Then Fanucci leaves, the little bell RINGING; and Signor Abbandando reluctantly moves to Vito.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitone.  How is your son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all well. It is clear that he has something difficult to tell the young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitone...I...Fanucci has a nephew. Vito looks at him a while, as the old man struggles to te him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you must give him my job. The old man nods, regretfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been kind to me since I was a boy; taken care of me, and been as a father.  I will always be grateful to you.  Thank you. Vito takes off his apron, and leaves, passing the youth w loiters by the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: making his way from the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitone! He turns, and Abbandando has followed him out of the shop holding a basket of some groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here...for your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...please understand...I cannot accept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito and his wife sit quietly at the table; the two are quiet and sad. Suddenly, we HEAR a noise, and Vito is astonished to see young man, PETER CLEMENZA, leaning out of the window on t other side of the air shaft which separates their apartme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Paisan!  Hold this for me until I ask for it.  Hurry up! Automatically Vito reaches over to the empty space at the air shaft, and takes the bundle of rags.  Clemenza's roun face is strained and urgent, obviously in some kind of trouble.  Suddenly, he closes the window and there is activity that we cannot see in the other apartment. Vito looks to his wife, and then closes the window and window dressing and takes the bundle into a private part his kitchen and begins to unwrap it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five oily guns.  He immediately wraps them again, and carries them to a private closet, and hides it, and retur to his wife.  He sits down back at the table; and she kno not to ask him what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito is walking through the crowded streets with a group workmen; they all wear work clothes, and paper hats on th heads. Vito looks to his left, and realizes that Clemenza is walking silently with him; by contrast, Clemenza dresses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have my goods still? Vito nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you look inside? Vito, his face impassive, shakes his head 'no.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in things that don't concern me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito and Clemenza drinking wine; they've become friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a friend who has a fine rug. Maybe your wife would like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no money for a rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He would give it away.  I know how to repay a consideration. Vito thinks, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men proceed up the hallway; Vito is impressed wit the opulence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend lives in a fine building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, the very best. Clemenza knocks on the door as though he is well known he then rings.  No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, he's not at home.  Oh, well, he wouldn't mind. Quickly and expertly he takes out a tool and pries open t door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito looks in awe at the luxurious apartment, which featu a fabulous rich red wool rug. Clemenza immediately moves some of the furniture away, an drops to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little help. Vito joins him, and the two begin rolling the rug.  We HE a BUZZER RING.  Clemenza immediately drops his side of th roll, and moves to the window.  He pulls a gun from his jacket. VIEW ON Vito watching.  He moves so he can see out the wi

dialogues.speaker: THEIR VIEW
dialogues.text: A Policeman stands at the exterior door, waiting.  He rin the buzzer again.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CLEMENZA
dialogues.text: cocking his gun.  Vito realizes that if the Policeman sho pursue it any further he is a dead man.  The Policeman gi up and leaves. Clemenza puts away his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men run up the steps, laughing, carrying the fine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are on their knees cutting the rug to fit the small room.  Carmella watches, holding the baby SANTINO.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMENZA
dialogues.text: Like a professional, cutting quickly, with the proper too He sings as he works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemenza knocks on the steel door of this downtown buildi Vito waits with him, holding some packages; and another youth, TESSIO, tall and thin and deadly waits with them. The door is lifted, and they are greeted by a bright, middle-aged Italian named AUGUSTINO who leads them into a machine shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, you waited for us. Clemenza looks up on a higher level.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: There is a nine year old boy, operating a drill press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son, Carmine...it's all right. The men then quickly open the packages they've brought; revealing gun, including a more sophisticated machine wea Augustino takes them and expertly begins to clean and prepare them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (to Vito)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paisan Augustino was a gunsmith in the Italian army.  We do each other favors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (while he works)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy is studying the flute.  He plays very well.  He helps me at night so we can buy him a silver flute someday.  Now he has one made of wood.  Carmine...play...play for my friends.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE BOY
dialogues.text: wide-eyed... he shuts off the press; and takes out a shab wooden flute.  And begins to play a simple and pure melod

dialogues.speaker: VITO
dialogues.text: listening.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINO
dialogues.text: proudly smiling, as he prepares the machine gun.

dialogues.speaker: TESSIO
dialogues.text: listening, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: The men listening, as the boy's father prepares their gun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tessio and Clemenza quickly load racks of cheap dresses. Vito sits behind the wheel of the truck.  He seems reserv and we get the impression that he is studying every move two friends are making.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemenza runs up a flight of stairs with an armful of dresses.  He knocks on a door, and a pretty HOUSEWIFE ans

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, I got a bargain on these dresses.  Five dollars each.  You gotta pay at least fifteen, maybe twenty in a store.  Look at them, first class. He holds the dresses up and the woman seems interested. handles a couple of them and stands aside so Clemenza can enter her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know which one I like best. She holds the dresses against her body, Clemenza approvin of each one; and then she goes to her purse and takes out five singles and gives them to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd look beautiful in all of these.  You should buy at least two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?  My husband will kill me if he knows I paid five dollars for one dress. She holds one up, then another.  She is torn.  Clemenza shakes his head and straightens the dress on her body.  H hand brushes her arm; she looks at him smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
