dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have two for five. She smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemenza jumps down the stairs, and out to the middle of street, where Vito and Tessio are waiting in the car with some of the stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What took so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She couldn't decide. Tessio and Clemenza each take more armsful of dresses and divide the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito, take the rest of the stock over to Dandine's warehouse; he'll move it to a wholesaler. The three part.  Vito drives the truck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito drives the truck through the downtown streets; he tu a corner and stops for a light. Suddenly, to his left, he sees the formidable figure of Fanucci. He grabs young Corleone by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: frightening, revealing the large circular scar, now heale

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, young fellow.  People tell me you're rich, you and your two friends.  Yet, you don't show enough respect to send a few dresses to my home.  You know I have three daughters. Vito says nothing.  Fanucci thumbs through the stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my neighborhood.  You and your friends have to show me a little respect, ah?  This truck you hijacked was in my neighborhood. You should let me wet my beak a little. Fanucci takes a few of the dresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand each of you cleared around six hundred dollars.  I expect two hundred dollars for my protection and I'll forget the insult.  After all, young people don't know the courtesies due a man like myself. Vito smiles at him and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise the police will come to see you and your wife and children will be dishonored and destitute. Of course, if my information as to your gains is incorrect, I'll dip my beak just a little.  Just a little, but no less than one hundred dollars, and don't try to deceive me, eh paisan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My two friends have my share of the money.  I'll have to speak to them after we deliver these to the wholesaler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell your friends I expect them to let me wet my beak in the same manner.  Don't be afraid to tell them.  Clemenza and I know each other well, he understands these things.  Let yourself be guided by him.  He has more experience in these matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (shrugging innocently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must understand, this is all new to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But thank you for speaking to me as a Godfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good fellow. He takes Vito's hands and clasps them in his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have respect.  A fine thing in the young.  Next time, speak to me first, eh?  Perhaps I can help you make your plans. Fanucci turns with the dresses draped over his arms, wavi to Vito. Vito throws the truck in gear, and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know that throughout this encounter he has seethed wit an icy rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wife serves a dinner for her husband and his two frien They discuss Fanucci as they eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he'd be satisfied with the two hundred dollars?  I think he would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That scar-faced bastard will find out what we got from the wholesaler. He won't take a dime less than three hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we don't pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (gestures, it's hopeless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know his friends...real animals. And his connections with the police. Sure he'd like us to tell him our plans so he can set us up for the cops and earn their gratitude. Then they would owe him a favor; that's how he operates.  We'll have to pay.  Three hundred, are we agreed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do? Clemenza doesn't even bother checking for Vito's opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say Fanucci has a license from Maranzalla himself to work this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like, why not give me fifty dollars each to pay Fanucci.  I guarantee he will accept that amount from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Fanucci says two hundred he means two hundred.  You can't talk with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll reason with him.  Leave everything in my hands.  I'll settle this problem to your satisfaction. Tessio and Clemenza regard him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never lie to people I've accepted as my friends.  Speak to Fanucci yourself tomorrow.  Let him ask you for the money, but don't pay it, and don't in any way quarrel with him.  Tell him you have to get the money and will send me as your messenger.  Let him understand that you're willing to pay what he asks, don't bargain.  I'll go to his house, and quarrel with him.  He likes me; enjoys explaining how things are here.  He uses ten sentences when he only needs one, so while he talks, I'll kill him. Clemenza, irritated, makes a large belch, and washes his food down with wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitone! (to Tessio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our driver has drunk too much wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (laughs at himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to kill Fanucci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (stern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, after that, what?  Joe 'Little Knife' Pisani; Willie Bufalino, maybe, Mr. Maranzalla himself, c'mon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanucci is not connected; he is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  You read it in the papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man informs to the police; this man allows his vengeance to be bought off... No, he is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm wrong, they will kill me. Both Clemenza and Tessio are impressed with their young friend; his willingness to risk his life on his perceptio of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ten piece Italian street band plays in front of the chu to commemorate the first night of the Festa di San Gennar People swarm in crowds, delighted by the music, as out of the church four men carry the statue of San Gennaro down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemenza moves along the booths that have been set up alo the street: sausage cooking on an open fire; pork livers sweetbeards.  He stops for a sandwich, and makes an irrit gesture when the vendor expects to be paid.  He crosses t church-sponsored booth with a great Wheel of Fortune, and slaps a dollar on a number.  Standing next to him is Vito they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three daughters are at church; he is alone.  It's important that you let his neighbors see you leave. Tessio has broken the latch on the skylight of his building. The wheel stops; they both lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Brother Carmello, even the church makes numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only the way we collect that's different. Vito has left while Clemenza jokes with the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito passes the booths of food, crossing toward a small a dark club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can still HEAR the crowds and music of the festa.  Vit enters; the club is empty, except for the large white fig sitting alone at a small table.  Fanucci barely acknowled Vito as he joins him. Without a word, Vito counts out two hundred dollars on th table.  Fanucci looks, then takes off his fedora and puts on the table over the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think there's only two hundred dollars under my hat. (he peeks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right.  Only two hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little short.  I've been out of work.  Let me owe you the money for a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, you're a sharp young fellow. How is it I've never noticed you before (he takes the two hundred and pours some wine for Vito)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too quiet for your own interest.  I could find some work for you to do that would be very profitable. (he rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hard feelings, eh?  If I can ever do you a service let me know. You've done a good job for yourself tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the musicians have left, but still families are walking the street, and stopping at the booths. Fanucci stands there a moment; he is known by everyone, a considers himself highly loved. Then Fanucci begins the walk through the festa, on his wa home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito silently moves along the rooftop; paralleling Fanucc walk. We HEAR the sounds of the festa, and every so often catch glimpse of the patterned lights, and the crowds below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walking through the crowded streets.  The statue of San Gennaro is arranged in some midnight religious ceremony. The VIEW LIFTS UP, to the rooftops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito makes the leap that separates two buildings; then crosses toward the large skylight in the center of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The procession in the streets is preceded by ten altar bo and the glittering Monstrance, something of an altar carr out into the streets. The priest begins this nocturnal service, as the crowds i the street kneel down in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanucci unlocks the door to his building; we can HEAR the services in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito tries the trap door on the roof; it is stuck firmly shut; despite Clemenza's instructions.  He struggles with it, but no luck. From the distance, the Choir begins to Latin.  Vito moves around the skylight, to an identical trap, tries this one it opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: performing the services in Latin.  The ten altar boys are attendance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito reaches down into the trap, and pulls out the newly oiled gun that has been left for him.  He slides down int the building.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fanucci proceeds up the staircase with loud, heavy steps. An OLD WOMAN on one of the flights sees him, and immediat moves to her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Signora?  You don't say 'good evening'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Good evening,' Signor Fanucci. She quickly disappears behind her door.  Fanucci laughs, continues up, singing to himself.  The MASS outside is always in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito climbs down from the attic, and finds Fanucci's rear door open.  He slips in, and makes his way past the open windows, out of which pour the music and chanting of the Mass.  Slowly and quietly he pulls them down, shut. He moves quietly to a glass door, and peeks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three young women, Fanucci's DAUGHTERS, laughing and talk

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON VITO
dialogues.text: A slip up.  Tessio had said they were out.  He steps outs to the alley where he can look into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER VIEW
dialogues.text: Fanucci opens the door of his apartment, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to wrap the gun.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE DAUGHTERS
dialogues.text: Their father greets them with a kiss; and a little religi gift he has bought for each.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUN
dialogues.text: wrapped in this primitive method of a silencer.  The VIEW TILTS to Vito, caught in the dilemma of having to kill al or none of them.  Then something catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small gray alley cat is attracted to the young man, com up to him and rubs itself against him.  Vito rubs the animal, speaking softly in Sicilian, then, gaining its confidence, lifts it up and carefully lets it into Fanucc apartment. He steps back, holding the gun.  We HEAR some Italian shouted in the house; a loud sound from the cat, and some the thumping footsteps of Fanucci.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON VITO
dialogues.text: holding the wrapped gun, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white blob of Fanucci opening the door and cursing in Italian as he throws the cat out.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON VITO
dialogues.text: squeezing the trigger; the muffled, but still LOUD BLAST resounding in the building.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON FANUCCI
dialogues.text: He holds onto the door frame, trying to stand erect, tryi to reach for his gun.  The force of his struggle has torn the buttons off his jacket and made it swing loose.  His is exposed but so is a spidery vein on the white shirtfro of his stomach.  Carefully, as if plunging a needle into this vein, Vito Corleone fires a second bullet. Fanucci falls to his knees, propping the door open, givin terrible groan.  We begin to hear the VOICES of girls ins the apartment. Vito quickly opens his wallet, removes the two hundred, quickly fires one last bullet into Fanucci's sweaty cheek Now the towel the gun was wrapped with catches fire, literally on Vito's hand; quickly he throws it to the ground, stamps it out...and disappears upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito moves like a cat along the rooftops; we HEAR the conclusion of the Mass down below.

dialogues.speaker: VITO
dialogues.text: Pausing; we can SEE the great spectacle of lights and candles on the streets below. He empties the gun of bullets and smashes the barrel agai the side of the roof ledge.  He reverses it in his hand, breaks the butt into two separate halves against the chim He smashes it again, and the pistol breaks into barrel an handle, two separate pieces. He then moves along the rooftop, dropping the two separat fragments into various air shafts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Priest, having completed the ceremony, follows as the Monstrance is carried off through the streets, as the Cho sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito is a dark figure, moving with agility across the rooftops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corpse that was Fanucci, stained with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The statue of San Gennaro, followed by the altar boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito's wife; her baby and several friends and neighbors s happily on the front stoop of their tenement.  Some of th men drink wine poured out of a pitcher; we can still HEAR the music and night sounds of the Festa. A neighbor is singing a Neapolitan song. Quietly, without a word, and with only a momentary glance from his wife, Vito joins the little group; takes a glass wine, and listens to the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: listening to the song.  He reaches out and takes the smal hand of his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santino, your papa loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is large, lit from the outside by a bright eveni We can see the outline of many toys on the shelves built along the wall.  We see the dark figure of Michael Corleo enter the room and approach the bed where his son Anthony lies curled in messy blankets.  Michael quietly arranges small hands and feet and covers the little boy.  Suddenly Anthony turns, his eyes open.  He is staring, perfectly awake, at his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you sleep? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like your party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got lots of presents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know the people who gave them to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were friends. He kisses his boy, and then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see my present for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving very early tomorrow, before you wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  How long will you be gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some day you will. Michael kisses him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is lit from a small night lamp on Michael's side the large bed. Kay is huddled in blankets, asleep.  Michael closes the d to his room, moves to his side of the bed, and glances do to the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE PILLOW
dialogues.text: is a child's drawing of a long limousine, with a man in a hat sitting in the back seat. An arrow pointing to him is marked "DAD." Under it, a nin year old's handwriting says: "Do you like it?  Check YES I liked it or NO __ I didn't like it." Michael turns, looking for a pencil, and moves to the dresser, where he places a check next to "YES." He starts to cross back toward his side of the bed, when turns, almost in her sleep:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael?  Why are the drapes open? His eyes dart back to the curved, beautifully leaded wind of the room.  The DRAPES are opened.  Then, without a second's hesitation, he leaps to the floor, still holding his son's drawing, as a spray of machine gun bullets swee across the windows; glass shattering all over the room. Kay screams out; rising, still half-asleep.  Michael craw toward her, and pulls her down to the floor to him. Then, for a moment, there is silence, soon filled by the shouts of men; as flashes of light sweep by the window, a guards with flashlights come running. Michael holds Kay to him, knowing they have both survived and then gently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go with the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the great floodlights are turned on, bathing la in an intense blue light. Groups of ordinarily dressed security men drawn in from a directions; a state of confusion prevails.  There is no s of the attackers.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW BY MICHAEL'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Michael is joined by Rocco Lampone, his gun drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still on the property. Maybe you better stay inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep them alive. Six men take up posts by Michael's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important. He returns inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The character of the summer estate has changed: bright floodlights illuminate the main points of entry: the main gate; the waterway; the stone wall that encompasses the estate on all sides. Several men with flashlights reinforce the guard at the m gate.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: Off in the distance, we see another group of men with flashlights combing the waterline.  We hear indistinguish shouts.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE KENNELS
dialogues.text: The wire gates are opened, and the trained dogs go out yelping into the outer edge of the estate.

dialogues.speaker: ROOFTOP
dialogues.text: One of Rocco's men turns the large floodlight scanning darkened forest areas, where men could hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men with flashlights and dogs.  Moving through the dark a

dialogues.speaker: LOOSE VIEW
dialogues.text: A small Corleone launch, with a bright spotlight slowly cruises the boundaries of the estate.  We SEE the silhoue of men with guns, quietly waiting and watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the bodyguards by the shattered windows of Michae bedroom. The curtains are drawn from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, the children, and some women servants have come down from the various rooms into the central living area, that can be most easily secured.  The little girl is still asleep; they make you think of an immigrant family, with their blankets and frightened faces, all waiting in a central room. Michael goes up to Kay, squeezes her hand, and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be all right.  We were lucky. She says nothing; but her face expresses the anger she fe over the jeopardy Michael has placed his children in.  Sh holds her young daughter in her arms. The door opens, and Rocco enters.  He quickly realizes he holding his gun in plain view in front of the family, and puts it away.  Michael moves to him, and they talk a dist away from Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family all seem to be okay in the other houses; your Mother's still sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sign of them yet; but they're still on the Estate. We HEAR loud shouting from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn you!  You're all nuts here, I'm not goin' to calm down...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VIEW
dialogues.text: Through the door, that Rocco opens. Deanna, in her nightgown, has been frightened by the gunshots; while Fredo in his bathrobe, tries to get her b into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deanna, will you get back into the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting out of here I said; these guys all have guns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo, can't you shut that woman up! (to Rocco's men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get her in here! The bodyguards, gracefully help Fredo bring the hysterica Deanna into the safety of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whimpering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to stay here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, what can I do, she's a hysterical woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave her alone!  You're talking as though she has no right to be frightened when there are machine guns going off in her backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocco)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have Tom Hagen meet me in the Harbor House.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Michael walks the short distance from his house, to the boathouse where he conducts his business away from his fa A small group of bodyguards, carrying machine guns, make walk with him from all sides, a respectful distance away. It gives the appearance of a lonely President moving in h compound, followed by teams of Secret Service men. The boathouse is already secured by teams of men, hastily wakened from their lodge house; a barracks-like structure where reinforcements are lodged just for this kind of emergency.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: In the distance, we can see the teams of men and dogs, wi their lights, guns and shouts, combing every inch of the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael alone in the great room.  He moves to a walk-in safe, quickly runs through the combination, and opens it. He takes out an envelope, and puts it into his pocket; there's a KNOCK on the door, and Hagen enters.  He had be asleep, and has quickly thrown on a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside the leaded windows, a disoriented Hagen sits down; Michael starts to talk to him; obviously about something very serious. The patrol securing the boathouse, walk past the window. Michael says something to Tom, who rises, and pulls the drapes, obscuring OUR VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael talks intimately to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot I can't tell you, Tom. I know that's upset you in the past; and you've felt that it was because of some lack of trust or confidence.  But it is because I do trust you that I've kept so much secret from you.  It's precisely that at this moment, you are the only one that I can completely trust.  In time, you'll understand everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods with this statement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your people... Neri... Rocco; you don't think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have confidence in their loyalty... but this is life and death, and Tom, you are my brother. Hagen in very moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey, I hoped...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Tom, just listen.  All my people are businessmen; their loyalty is based on that.  One thing I learned from my father is to try to think as the people around you think...and on that basis, anything is possible. Fredo has a good heart, but he is weak...and stupid, and stupid people are the most dangerous of all.  I've kept you out of things, Tom, because I've always known that your instincts were legitimate, and I wanted you to know very little of things that would make you an accomplice, for your own protection. I never blamed you for the setbacks the family took under Sonny; I know you were in a position of limited power, and you did your best to advise and caution him.  What I am saying is that now, for how long I do not know, you will be the Don. If what I think has happened is true; I will leave tonight, and absolutely no one will know how to contact me.  And even you are not to try to reach me unless it is absolutely necessary.  I give you complete power: over Neri... Fredo, everyone.  I am trusting you with the lives of my wife and children, and the future of this family, solely resting on your judgment and talent.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN
dialogues.text: A man who has steadily declined over the last five years, realizing that total power and responsibility is being placed on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But Tom, you must know that I do this only because I believe you are the only one who is capable of taking over for me.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: taking out the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've prepared this; have had it for over a month.  It won't explain everything; but indicates where I will be, so in a sense, it is my life. (he hands the envelope to Hagen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, there are three tasks that must be executed immediately.  Pop would have given those to Luca -- You knew Pop as well as anyone, act as though you were him.  It discusses Kay as well; that will be the most difficult.  The men who tried to kill me tonight, will never leave the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will we...be able to get who ordered it out of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.  Unless I'm very wrong...they're already dead. Killed by someone inside...very frightened that they botched it. That's why I am going to disappear in a few minutes, and leave everything to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you're wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm wrong... There is a KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't think I'm wrong. (he indicates the knock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The door opens; it is Rocco; Michael rises, after making knowing glance toward Tom, and moves to talk quietly to a frightened and agitated Rocco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of men with flashlights and guns lead Michael, To and Rocco to the stone bridge spanning the stream which r through the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael's dispassionate face, looking down.  THE VIEW MOV to Hagen's, and then down to the murky water under the bridge, where we see the bodies of three strangers, lying the moving water; machine-type guns nearby, with their throats cut.  Light from the many flashlights illuminates the grotesque scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fish them out. Several of the men wade down into the stream; Rocco helps and even Tom steps down to get a better look at who they were.  They are total strangers; Rocco examines the type guns they used. When they climb back onto the ground, Michael is gone. Everyone notices it, but no one says anything. Hagen stands there, holding the envelope Michael had give him in his hand. He realizes that now, he is the DON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of the bodies.  Tomorrow morning I want a report made to the local police, and paper, that some explosives we keep on the property were accidentally ignited. The men respond; Hagen makes the lonely walk back to the lighted section of the compound, which now resembles a prison camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senate is in session; Senator Geary is on the floor during a vote.  An aide approaches him, with a slip of pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator steps behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Hagen, you've got ten minutes. He flicks the switch of a small tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the tape will be running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I've come with good news; the Corleone family has done you a favor. The Senator immediately shuts the tape recorder off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know you're a busy man, with plenty of enemies -- we saw the opportunity to do you a favor, and we did.  No strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know there's a Senate Investigating Committee recently set up; we thought it would be unfortunate if they were to trace anything though-provoking to your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one can trace anything to me; I pride myself on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you gamble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little; what's so thought- provoking about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you owe markers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe two, three thousand dollars. Hagen leans forward, and deposits a handful of paper on t Senator's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corleone family has paid them off for you...as an expression of our esteem. Geary quickly looks through the paid markers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's thirty grand worth of paid off markers -- I never owed that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our mistake.  But what does it matter; it was our money. (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't even expect thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You paid off thirty grand I never owed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll keep it quiet; the people who know are trustworthy...the Committee needn't find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's the price of their not finding out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple.  Be friendly like us.  Not hostile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he despises Hagen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks...friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are more men on duty than usual; not that there are guns apparent, but it's clear that the boundaries are bei patrolled.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW BY MICHAEL'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Kay exits her house, followed by her children; she helps them into her station wagon like any housewife, and drive along the path leading to the main gate. She's about to drive through, when one of the men steps i front of her, raising his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (graciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Corleone.  We're not to let you through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disbelieving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could just give us a list, we'll pick up anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose orders are these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hagen's, ma'am. We notice Hagen walking to them in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW THROUGH THE GATE
dialogues.text: Hagen approaches the car; Kay gets out so they can talk a from the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to explain this myself... I had business in Carson City. He walks with her a little way from the others; the child run out of the station wagon, and start to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Michael's request...for your safety.  We can send out for anything you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to stay in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Within the compound will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was supposed to take the children to New England next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's off now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to see my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, Michael didn't tell me a lot; and what he did tell me, I can't repeat.  But the responsibility for you and the kids was the most important thing he left me with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does this go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Kay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I a prisoner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the way we look at it. Angrily, without another word, Kay turns away from him, a walks to her children, ignoring the running station wagon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The luxury liner making its way across the Atlantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PURSER followed by several white uniformed associates knocks on the door of something designated the "Leonardo Suite." He is holding a telegram. The door opens, and a tanned Merle peeks out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the telegram)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry to disturb you but we have received two telegrams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...come in. This entourage enters the suite, an impressive and beautifully spacious luxury suite.  Connie is relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  One is from our office in New York.  The check that you wrote for your passage has been returned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you wire your bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other telegram is from your bank.  Your account has been closed and the company is warned not to extend any credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it in Naples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company hopes so.  But for now, we have orders to change your accommodations. And with that, the men in white begin to pack Connie and Merle's luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie and Merle are attempting to sleep in the miniature cabin in bunk beds.  The little space is crowded with the trunks and luggage.  Merle can barely hang onto the bunk, the boat pitches so violently below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train speeds across the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the corridor, a porter advances, and knocks on the door of a stateroom.  A voice tells him to enter.  OUR VI enters with him as he carries a tray of lunch.  From this POV we see Michael Corleone sitting in the compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ordered lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it right there. The porter does so; as he places the tray down, he catche glimpse of a second person in the compartment with Michae

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: A very fierce, almost maniacal looking man, BUSSETTA.  He nods that the porter should leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. The porter takes his advice and leaves quickly, closing t door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Michael and his mysterious companion have lunch together the moving train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The empty parking lot of the Gulfstream track, on an off- race day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael sits behind the wheel of a nondescript late model car.  Bussetta sits in the rear. Another car swings into the lot.  Michael starts his car, and pulls out of the lot; the second car following.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: This car pulls out and begins to follow them.  Michael glances back by adjusting the rear view mirror, and nods Bussetta. Michael's car begins to slow down, allowing the other car overtake them. The overtaking car hesitates a moment, moving side by sid with them. Michael glances toward the driver.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VIEW
dialogues.text: We recognize Johnny Ola, who waves a greeting to Michael, and then continues on to lead him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ola's car leads Michael's through a middle-class suburban area of $30,000 to $40,000 homes.  There are small channe with sporting and fishing boats parked near the houses. Ola's car pulls up in front of a very simple, tract-type home.  Michael's car parks nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (to Bussetta)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll wait in the car. Ola has gotten out of his car and walks up the little pat to the front door.  Michael waits. Ola rings the bell, and after a moment, a rather pretty, middle-aged WOMAN answers, remaining behind the screen do Ola says a few things to her and she disappears, leaving door open. Ola comes down the steps, looks at Michael, nodding to hi Ola then gets into his car and drives off.  Michael walks the walkway and enters the little house, closing the door behind him. This woman, TERRI ROTH, is in the kitchen, looking out at Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to make lunch.  How about a tuna fish sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Roth. She hurries halfway up the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyman...HYMAN, your friend is here. (turning to Michael)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go right upstairs, Mr. Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. He continues upstairs; she goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give a yell when lunch is ready. Michael continues up to a small den on the second floor; can HEAR the sound of a baseball game coming over the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael enters the den: it's very comfortable, but somewh like a senior citizen's retirement home in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VIEW
dialogues.text: There, sitting before the television is a small man in hi middle sixties, thin, with a wizened face, looking like a small-time retired Jewish businessman.  This is HYMAN ROT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, this is almost over.  You follow the baseball games?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for a few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like sporting events -- I really enjoy watching them in the afternoon. One of the things I love about this country.  I loved baseball ever since Arnold Rothstein fixed the World Series of 1919...I heard you had some trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a mistake; people behaving like that, with guns. (he shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my understanding we left all that behind.  But, let me tell you, the important thing is that you're all right.  Good health is the most important thing; more than success; more than power; more than money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incident of the other night is a nuisance that I can take care of. I came to you because I want nothing to affect our agreement; I wanted to clear everything I'm going to do with you, just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a considerate young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a great man, Mr. Roth, I have much to learn from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However I can help you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rosato Brothers have performed services for you in the past; I understand that they are under your protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do favors for each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technically, they are still under the Clemenza wing of the Corleone Family, now run by Frankie Pentangeli.  After Clemenza died, the Rosatos wanted territory of their own.  Pentangeli refused, and came to me, asking for permission to eliminate them.  I, of course, knew of their relationship with you, and in gratitude for your help with the Tropicana matter, turned him down.  Pentangeli was furious, and paid one hundred and fifty thousand dollars to have me killed. I was lucky and he was stupid. I'll visit him soon. (leaning toward the old man, sincerely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The important thing is that nothing jeopardize our plans, yours and mine.  This thing of ours, that we will build. The old man touches Michael's hand, warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is more important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pentangeli is a dead man; do you object?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always bad for business; but you have no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's done.  I must choose his replacement: it cannot be Rosato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you must keep control of your family. He turns to Michael, turning the volume higher on the television, and moving closer to his young partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, these things are unimportant.  Who should be the manager of a dime store, Joe or Jack?  Unimportant.  You do what you think is right.  You're a young man, and I'm old and sick.  What we do together in the next few months will be history, Michael; it has never been done before.  We will do this historical thing together, and even your Father could never dream it would be possible.  We are bigger than U.S. Steel, you and me... because in America, anything is possible! (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But soon I will be dead, and it will all belong to you. There is a KNOCK on the door, and Terri Roth pushes the d open with her hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness, you'll rupture your eardrums, Hyman. She puts the tray down, and turns down the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sinister Bussetta waits patiently in the rear seat of the car, outside Roth's modest house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black Cadillac moves down the street, slowed by the Festivities of the Festa that is in progress: people mill around, buying souvenirs at the many stands set up. Sausage and grilled meats are prepared, just as they were years ago.  Electric lights are strung from the street lamps, and brightly colored banners pronounce the "Festa the Madonna."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy Cicci drives, frustrated that he cannot go any fast Next to him, Frankie Pentangeli sits, catching a few seco snooze.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The black car pulls up; another car that had been followi it parks nearby. One of Pentangeli's button men gets out of the car, and steps into a small Italian restaurant; he exits quickly, nods affirmatively toward Pentangeli's Cadillac. The group of them step out quickly, men huddled around Pentangeli, and enter the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant is quite empty, despite the excitement out the street. Pentangeli immediately sits at a table with a tall, dark, snappily dressed young man, CARMINE ROSATO. Nearby, on the other side of the room is Rosato's brother TONY, seated with a group of their men. At another table in the restaurant is a table of Pentange people: they are joined by bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosato, where's your brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting right behind you. Pentangeli glances behind himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't want to talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We worked it all out beforehand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we going to eat or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, on me.  I got Diner's Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it; I'm suddenly without an appetite.  You're making big trouble, Carmine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't straight with us, Frankie, what else could we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could have talked first, saved a lot of running around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wasn't listening, you didn't want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I look like I'm listening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want Brooklyn one hundred percent.  No more taxes to you.  We want to be only loosely connected with your family -- sort of a under-family all of our own.  Then we can act on all internal matters without talking.  Also we want you to inform Michael Corleone that we can deal directly with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little hungry, maybe I'll order something.  Joe. (one of his men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me some bracciole or something. And pay cash. (to Rosato)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in return for these concessions, what do you do for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will release the hostages, number one.  Number two, we're here for you to count on when you need us.  We're independent, but we're here if you need us.  In general, we'll cooperate with you and your businesses, and you in turn will cooperate with us.  Pari persu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pari Persu; what the fuck is Pari persu...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lawyer went over this beforehand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What assurances do I have that there will be no more kidnapping, no more hits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same assurance we got from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I say shove it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Carmine Fucillo and Tony Blue DeRosa will need to be fitted for slabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know if there's a way I'll go to the commission and the commission will side with me.  That puts me and the other New York families against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got friends in the commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about Italians!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Michael Corleone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He supports me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, yes... maybe no. One of Pentangeli's men approaches with a plate of Italia food. Pentangeli stands up, angered by this remark of Rosato's; pushes the dish of food out of the surprised Bodyguard's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drove old Pete Clemenza to his grave, Carmine; you and your brother.  Turning on him; trouble in his territories -- you and your demands.  I hold you responsible, just as though you shot him in the head.  And I ain't gonna let that go for long! Pentangeli walks out of the restaurant; there's a little tension between the bodyguards of the two factions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Five-Angels... He gives him the arm. Frankie's face turns red, like he wants to have it out he and now; but Willy Cicci calms his down, and they all mak their move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pentangeli gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody I hate calls me Five-Angels to my face! He slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of the old estate of Don Corleone.  By now, the wall has been torn down, and the other houses sold off. His car is parked; Pentangeli steps out, still angry over the confrontation.  As he approaches the house, he notice something strained about the bodyguards who discreetly gu his house.  No one seems to want to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up? Pentangeli glances over to the front door foyer.

dialogues.speaker: PENTANGELI'S VIEW
dialogues.text: The strange and silent Bussetta, the man who now always travels with Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pentangeli enters; he sees his WIFE, standing oddly in th hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Michael Corleone...Dove?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in your study. He knows it is very very serious for Michael to be here i his home. He automatically moves into his study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael stands quietly in the room.  This was once his father's study, although it is totally redecorated. Pentangeli starts sweating, and moves toward the young Do and kisses his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Corleone, I wish you let me know you was coming.  We could have prepared something for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want you to know I was coming.  You heard what happened in my home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, yes, we was all relieved...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my home!  In the same room where my wife was sleeping; where my children come in their pajamas, and play with their toys. He's terrified Pentangeli with his anger; then, just as suddenly, he talks quietly, calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to help me take my revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, anything.  What is it I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to settle these troubles with the Rosato Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just going to contact you, Michael; we just had a 'sit-down' - in fact, I just come from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to settle on their terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, I don't understand.  Don't ask me to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me; do as I ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be the beginning of the end for my family.  How can I keep all my other territories in like if I let two wise-guys stand up and demand this and that, and then give it to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie...do you respect me?  Do I have your loyalty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always... But sometimes I don't understand.  I know I'll never have your kind of brains, in big deals. But Mike, this is a street thing. And Hyman Roth in Miami is behind the Rosato Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you want me to lay down to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly, but convincing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie, Roth tried to have me killed.  I'm sure it was him, but I don't know yet why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Michael, then let's hit 'em now, while we still got the muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was my father's old study. When I was a kid, we had to be quiet when we played near here. When I was older, I learned many things from him here.  I was happy that this house never went to strangers; first Clemenza took it over, and then you.  My father taught me, in this room, never to act until you know everything that's behind things.  Never.  If Hyman Roth sees that I interceded with you in the Rosato Brothers' favor, he'll think his relationship with me is still sound.  I'm going somewhere to meet him tomorrow.  We have friends in some very important business that we're making.  Do this for me; you make the peace with the Rosato Brothers on their terms.  Let the word out that I forced you; you're not happy wit hit, but acquiesced, just because of me.  It will get back to Hyman Roth.  Do this, Frankie.  You can trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mike.  I'll go along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. They embrace; Michael kisses him.  He looks at the young Don, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money trays are carefully unloaded from the gaming tables, and put on a cart with others. The cart, preceded and followed by security guards, is th wheeled through the casino, into a private, counting room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards leave the room; the door is locked after them, leaving only Hagen.  Neri and an ACCOUNTANT, a very fat m The numbered boxes are opened, and cash and checks are spread out on the counting table. The accountant begins with amazing speed and skill, to co and divide the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen percent skim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five this time. The accountant stops, and looks up to Neri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike wants it. Neri nods, and the accountant continues.  Neri opens a do allowing a sandy-haired man, a COURIER, into the room.  T cream is placed into his pouch personally by Neri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've never sent this much with one courier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the courier)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your plans are a little different this time.  You skip Miami, and go straight to Geneva.  It's to be deposited to this number. (handing him a small envelope)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's got to be there by Monday morning, no slip-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I was 'picked-up' last trip. That hour layover I had at Kennedy. I went over and bought a paper... Neri has finished putting the 'creamed' money into the po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those were our people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, just thought you should know. He is just about to close and lock the pouch, when Hagen gestures that he should wait, and adds more stacks of carefully packaged bills into the pouch.  Then Neri locks it, and handcuffs it to the courier's arm, looking inquiringly at Hagen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them count. The courier is shown out through a private door, and then the first door is opened.  Two accountants come in with t guards, and the trays are opened, and the counting proces is begun all over again, this time with the State Tally sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courier continues on his way; followed by Hagen and N

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to ask questions, Tom, there's three million dollars cash in that pouch; Mike is gone and I have no word from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al, as far as you're concerned, I'm the Don.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know you haven't gone into business for yourself? This hurts Tom; but he is a reasonable man, and he knows owes Neri some explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been through a lot with us so I'm going to give you the truth. Mike knows it was someone within the compound that set him up for that hit.  So nobody is to know where he is, not you, not Rocco, not even his brother Fredo.  Sorry, Al, I know how you feel about Mike...but he still remembers Tessio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is led to a desolate, night-lit private dock.  He followed by the ever-present Bussetta, and they are helpe onto a light-weight, luxury cabin cruiser.  The crew cast off various ropes, and the boat sets out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seaplane lands nicely by the private Corleone harbor; Hagen disembarks with his inevitable overloaded briefcase He continues down the ramp, past several Buttonmen, dress in summer casual attire, and who resemble secret service rather than thugs. His wife THERESA lies on a blanket on the great lawn, wit her youngest children, who run to their father for a kiss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've invited Mama, Sandra and the kids for barbecue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Kay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't find her.  She's been so broody, sticks to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagen and Sonny's boys are throwing a football around on lawn; the littler kids running after them. Coals are burning in the old style stone barbecue, and several tables are set for the family. In the distance, there is always evidence of the bodyguar Theresa, Mama and Sandra prepare the steaks. Hagen relaxes in a sports shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me try Kay. He crosses the lawn, to the house on the beach where Mich and his family live.  Is about to knock on the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pop, heads up! The football is flying in his direction; he catches it an throws it back.  Then he cracks the door open, and peeks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay? He steps in, the beautiful summer living room is neat, bu empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone hungry? He moves through the house more quickly; into the dining recreation room areas.  A cat jumps off a pile of cushion and runs across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone, Tom. Sandra has followed him into Michael's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Barretts from Rubicon Bay came by in a new speedboat.  Rocco tried to say she wasn't in, but Kay spotted them and asked if they would take her and the kids for a ride.  That was three hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't someone tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to tell you alone; your wife doesn't know what's going on. Hagen rushes out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagen moves quickly out of Michael's house; moving across the lawn to the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad! This time he ignores the thrown ball, and moves directly Rocco, who is by some men near the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I went down to the Barrett house.  But she's gone.  They drove her and the kids to North Tahoe airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in my house.  Willy tried, but it would have taken some strong-arm to stop her, and he figured you wouldn't want that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to one of the men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a Scotch and water. The man hurries behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took a flight to San Francisco. We figure she's going to connect to New Hampshire; her parents' place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let him down. He swallows the drink down in several gulps.  And then lo up to his men watching him.  He's embarrassed to have sho such weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let me think a minute. Rocco clears the men out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, give me a minute. Rocco gone, Hagen moves behind the enormous bar, and pour himself a giant drink.  He drinks that, and calms himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Christ, Pop.  It was so good when you were alive.  I felt I could handle anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful coastal view of a tropical Caribbean city.  A extraordinary view, high buildings, palm trees, all set right on the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the cruiser, Bussetta a little distance away, watching but never speaking.  The dark-skinned CAPTAIN of the crui keeps pointing repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Habana, Habana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Bussetta are driven in a Mercury sedan, makin its way through the streets of Havana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded streets, occasional roving bands playing for the tourists; there is much evidence of tourism: Americans walking through the streets with cameras.  Occasionally, see a Cuban with a row of numbers attached to his hat, carrying a big sheet of the daily lottery numbers.  From of these street impressions, the city is booming with activity, but there is also much evidence of whores and pimps and little children begging in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The big American car stops at an intersection.  Bussetta sitting in the forward passenger side; while Michael is i the back.  He hears tapping on the window; he turns and s four Cuban boys tapping on his window and extending their hands, and rubbing their stomachs as though they were hun The Cuban driver rolls down his window and shouts them aw in Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is led through a beautiful wooden lobby of the hotel, done in Spanish style, apparently just recently completed.  He is approached by a thin, mousy man, SAM RO who ushers him toward the casino entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Mr. Corleone, I'm Sam Roth. Welcome to the Capri; my brother's upstairs.  You wanta take a rest before you see him, or can I get you something, anything at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine. He leads Michael into the main casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it!  We think it makes Vegas look like the corner crap game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, Jake, come over here.  Mike, I want you to meet Jake Cohen; he manages the casino for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appreciating Michael's status)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Corleone. Sam turns to Bussetta and extends his glad-hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you, I'm sure... He gets no response whatsoever from Bussetta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An extremely tall, well-built Cuban, tanned and wearing a attractive mustache, LEON, in his middle forties, reads f a prepared paper.  His sentences are translated by a smal man, standing to his rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most respected gentlemen, allow me to welcome you to the City of Havana, the Republic of Cuba on behalf of His Excellency, Fulgencio Batista. THE VIEW BEGINS TO MOVE along the various men gathered fo this meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to thank this distinguished group of American Industrialists, for continuing to work with Cuba, for the greatest period of prosperity in her entire history. Mr. William Proxmiro, representing the General Fruit Company... Messrs. Corngold and Dant, of the United Telephone and Telegraph Company; Mr. Petty, regional Vice-President of the Pan American Mining Corporation; and, of course, our friend Mr. Robert Allen, of South American Sugar.  Mr. Nash of the American State Department.  And Mr. Hyman Roth of Miami, and Michael Corleone of Nevada representing our Associates in Tourism and Leisure Activities.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE ENTIRE GROUP
dialogues.text: Leon pauses to take a drink of water.  Then proudly, he lifts a shiny yellow telephone for all to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President would like to take this opportunity to thank U T&T for their lovely gift: a solid gold telephone!  He thought all you gentlemen would care to take a look at it. He hands the heavy phone set to one of his aides, and it passed in turn to each of the men in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Excellency, perhaps you could discuss the status of rebel activity and how this may affect our businesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He receives the telephone, and glances at it before passi it on to Hyman Roth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  The rebel movement is basically unpopular, and since July of 1958 has been contained in the Oriente Province, in the mountains of the Sierra Muestre. Michael passes the phone on to Roth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We began a highly successful offensive against them in March, and activities within the city itself are at a minimum.  I can assure you we'll tolerate no guerrillas in the casinos or swimming pools! General subdued laughter.

dialogues.speaker: A CUBAN STREET
dialogues.text: Police are stopping traffic.  Michael's Mercury is among cars; a police officer, seeing that some important person being driven, walks up to the driver.  He leans forward, says something in Spanish to the driver. The driver, in turn, leans over to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it will just be a short time and they'll let us through. Michael looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VIEW
dialogues.text: The old building has been totally surrounded by police an military vehicles.  Right at this moment, they are waitin lazily, but soldiers are there with automatic weapons rea There is a momentary commotion inside the building, and t men brace up.  A Captain of the Army detachment says something in Spanish over a megaphone; and his men put th weapons at the ready, as other policemen lead a group of civilians out of the building with their hands up. They are moved over to some military truck, where they ar frisked before being loaded. All of a sudden, one of the civilian rebels breaks loose, and rushes toward the command vehicle.  He hurls himself into the vehicle, as two police try to pull him out.  A second later, and there is an explosion; the man obviousl having hidden a grenade on his body, sacrificing his own life to take the life of the Captain. There is a commotion, but the military quickly quell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching.  The police rush to Michael's car and guide it outside of the trouble area.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: as they lead and escort the Mercury out of the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some glasses; rum is poured into them; then Coca Cola. Quarter limes are squeezed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rum... Coca Cola...a squeeze of fresh lime... Sam prepares the drinks for his brother, Hyman, and a gro of men, including Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuba Libres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told the Cubans now call this drink: "La Mentira."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't speak Spanish, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means... "The Lie." A moment's hesitation, then a few of the men laugh.  Now Cubans in white carry a table which has a lovely small ca on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cake is here. They all raise their glasses to the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday! Roth glances at the cake and its inscription, is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope my age is correct: I am always accurate about my age. Some laugh.  He nods, and they begin to cut it, put a pie on plates, and carry them to the different men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything we've learned in Vegas is true here; but we can go further. The bigger, the swankier, the plusher the store, the more a sense of legitimacy, and the bigger business we do. (looking at the plate brought to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smaller piece.  What we've proposed to the Cuban Government is that it put up half the cash on a dollar for dollar basis. (accepting a smaller piece)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  We can find people in the United States who will put up our share for a small piece of the action, yet we will retain control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred million dollars.  But only if this Government relaxes its restrictions on importing building materials; we'll need some new laws, too, but that will be no difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are import duties now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much as seventy percent.  Also, I'm working out an arrangement with the Minister of Labor so that all our pit bosses, stick-men and Dealers, can be considered specialized technicians eligible for two year visas.  As of now they're only allowed in Cuba for six months at a time.  In short, we're in a full partnership with the Cuban Government.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: is handed a piece of cake.  Roth moves over to a folder o documents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are applications from Friends all over the States.  I understand Santo Virgilio in Tampa is trying to make his own deal.  Well, the Cuban Government will brush him off. The Lakeville Road Boys are going to take over the Nacionale here. I'm planning a new hotel casino to be known as Riviera.  The new Capri will go to the Corleone Family.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The cake is sliced and carried to each of the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there's the Sevilla Biltmore; the Havana Hilton, which is going to cost twenty-four million -- Cuban banks will put up half, the Teamsters will bankroll the rest. Generally, there will be friends for all our friends including the Lieutenant Governor of Nevada; Eddie Levine of Newport will bring in the Pennino Brothers, Dino and Eddie; they'll handle actual casino operations. And seeing that all of his friends have been served, Roth raises his fork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw an interesting thing today. A man was being arrested by the Military Police; probably an urban guerrilla.  Rather than be taken alive, he exploded a grenade hidden in his jacket, taking the command vehicle with him. The various men look up as Michael eats his cake, wonderi what the point of it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It occurred to me: the police are paid to fight, and the Rebels are not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, that occurred to me.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON ROTH
dialogues.text: He understands Michael's point, if the others do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This country has had rebels for the last fifty years; it's part of their blood.  Believe me, I know... I've been coming here since the twenties; we were running molasses out of Havana when you were a baby. To trucks owned by your father. (he chuckles warmly over the memory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk when we're alone. And he returns his attention to the men who are gathered with him on his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael sits alone with the old man, on a terrace that overlooks the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to be careful what you say in front of the others... they frighten easy.  It's always been that way, most men frighten easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're making a big investment in Cuba.  That's my only concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My concern is that the three million never arrived at Batista's numbered account in Switzerland. He thinks it's because you have second thoughts about his ability to stop the rebels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money was sent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have to trace it.  Michael, people here look at me as a reliable man.  I can't afford not to be looked on as a reliable man.  But you know all that; there's nothing you can learn from me.  You shouldn't have to put up with a sick old man as a partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't consider anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except the President of the United States. He laughs slyly, as though this is some private joke betw them.  Then his laughter becomes a cough, which he painfu stifles with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only I could live to see it, kid; to be there with you.  How beautifully we've done it, step by step.  Here, protected, free to make our profits without the Justice Department, the FBI; ninety miles away in partnership with a friendly government.  Ninety miles, just a small step, looking for a man who desperately wants to be President of the United States, and having the cash to make it possible.
