dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be there to see it; you'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone has just rung; Michael listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have your call to Tahoe, Nevada, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (click, click)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom?  Tom, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Tom's out of town.  This is Rocco.  Who is this? Michael is openly disturbed that Hagen is not there.  He hangs up without answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Hagen steps out of a taxicab a bit tentatively, and t steps toward the door of a pleasant New England house.  H rings the bell and waits, hat in hand.  A moment later, t door opens, and Kay is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised to see you, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out to the yard, where we can see glimpses of little Anth playing by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't love a man like that; I can't live with him, I can't let him be father to my children.  Look. The little boy, moodily by himself.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KAY
dialogues.text: obviously moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not like a little boy... he doesn't talk to me; he doesn't want to play; he doesn't like other children, he doesn't like toys. It's as though he's waiting for the time he can take his Father's place. (almost in tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what he told me when he was four years old.  He said he had killed his Grandfather...

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN
dialogues.text: listening, calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He said he had shot his Grandfather with a gun, and then he died in the garden.  And he asked me... he asked me, Tom, if that meant now his father would shoot him out of... revenge. (she cries)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does a four year old boy learn the word... 'revenge'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay... Kay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a family is this... are we human beings?  He knows his Father killed his Uncle Carlo.  He heard Connie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that's true.  But Kay, just for the sake of an argument, let's assume it is, I'm not saying it is, remember, but... What if I gave you what might be some justification for what he did... or rather some possible justification for what he possibly did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first time I've seen the lawyer side of you, Tom.  It's not your best side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, just hear me out.  What if Carlo had been paid to help get Sonny killed?  What if his beating of Connie that time was a deliberate plot to get Sonny out into the open? Then what?  And what if the Don, a great man, couldn't bring himself to do what he had to do, avenge his son's death by killing his daughter's husband?  What if that, finally, was too much for him, and he made Michael his successor, knowing that Michael would take that load off his shoulders, would take that guilt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not the same as when I met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he were, he'd be dead by now. You'd be a widow.  You'd have no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean?  Come on, Tom, speak out straight once in your life.  I know Michael can't, but you're not Sicilian, you can tell a woman the truth; you can treat her like an equal, a fellow human being. There is a long silence. Then Hagen shakes his head; he can tell her no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you told Michael what I've told you today, I'm a dead man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is it finally over?  I want it to be over before my baby is born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I hope soon; but it's not over yet, and that's why you and the kids have to come back to me. He looks at her; it's clear that he has been entrusted wi her safety and her children's. He is a kind, good man, and seems very nervous and overwrought.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Little Anthony is pressing his face against the glass pan as though he senses the adults are discussing something o importance to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baccarat table.  Busy, hundred dollar bills being pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Corleone; Mr. Freddie Corleone, telephone please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE CRAP TABLES
dialogues.text: The play is fast; pit boss presiding; but no sign of Fred

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone for Mr. Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PART OF THE CASINO
dialogues.text: We see Neri, ominous, presiding over the entire store.  H picks up a pit telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's backstage. (and hangs up disgustedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo is entertaining two showgirls done up in feathers a what-have-you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, you got fifteen minutes before the finale!  I want to show you a trick with feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go away; wait a minute. He takes the phone; we can catch a VIEW of the show going from the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Okay.  Who?  Mikey?  But... Si... si, caposco. (in Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... how much?  I understand. Jesus, three million... I won't let you down.  Sure. He hangs up thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie; we still got twelve minutes before the finale!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... some other time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a light rain.  Pentangeli steps out of his car; points to Willy Cicci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait in the car. He walks up the street, to the bar, where he is greeted b the tall, handsome Carmine Rosato.  They shake hands. Pentangeli looks in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosato has put a crisp one hundred dollar bill in his han folded sharply in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lucky C note for our new deal. He puts his arm around Pentangeli, and they walk into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar is fairly empty; and very dark.  Pentangeli and Rosato step up to the bar; the bartender momentarily stop polishing glasses to pour a couple of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were all real happy about your decision, Frankie; you're not goin' to regret it. He holds up the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the C-note.  I take it like an insult. Suddenly, a garrote is thrown around Pentangeli's throat; and he is forcefully yanked back into the shadows, all th way into a wooden telephone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The folded hundred dollar bill resting on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: We see only Pentangeli's feet and legs, struggling.  We H the terrible sounds of a man being strangled.

dialogues.speaker: ROSATO
dialogues.text: Calm, and then he sees something that disturbs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, your friend the cop! Suddenly, the side door opens, and a shaft of sunlight cu through the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything all right in there, Ritchie?  The door was open.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Pentangeli's feet stop moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just cleaning up. (strained voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that something on the floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here; not a cop, not here! Two figures race through the shadows and race through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to his partner, in uniform)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stutz!  Watch out, Stutz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that a patrol car had stopped for its routine visi STUTZ, the second patrolman, is just stepping out of his car; Pentangeli's bodyguard, seeing the commotion, leaps Three men, including Rosato, rush out.  There is gunfire; Cicci is wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patrolmen is grazed across the face; trying to stop t flow of blood with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: The three assailants jump into the car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stricken Pentangeli comes back to life.  He can barel move his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bastard.  The dirty bastard, he gave me a C-note.  He gave me a C- note. He sees the patrolman leaning over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sergeant is on the car radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie Pentangeli murder attempt. Patrolman Stutz shot.  Sahara Lounge - Utica Avenue and Claredon Road.  White Cadillac three or four men took off from scene.  Need ambulance; Stutz is bad.  Taking Pentangeli into custody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wizened face, pale.  Right now, though, his eyes have sparkle as he watches three million dollars in cold cash being counted on a card table in front of him. His brother Sam is present, and the sandy-haired Courier, little nervous; the one who had left from the Tropicana w the Corleone skim-money.  Also Johnny Ola.  The money is evidently all there; Roth picks up a packet; probably a hundred thousand dollars, and throws it over to the Couri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it fast; I don't want to chance him being seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the arrangements?  How can I be sure about the arrangements?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.  You're under our protection; the Corleone family will never find you. Ola leads the Courier to the adjoining room where two smartly dressed Military (Cuban) Police are standing, and civilian.  The Courier sees them, looks back to Ola.  One the police steps forward, placing the Courier under arres handcuffing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's this? The other takes the packet of money, and hands it to the civilian, who places it in the briefcase he carries.  The other officer kneels down and fastens leg manacles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arrangements... YOU BASTARDS! What... The Captain strikes him expertly across the side of his h with his pistol. Ola closes the door on this scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo Corleone steps out of a car, squints up at the suns and palm trees.  He is holding on tightly to a small satc which he won't let the bellman carry along with his other things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Fredo in a brother's embrace; they kiss each other.  Fredo is still in his jacket, holding the satchel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey.  How are you? He glances up at Bussetta, who doesn't say a word.  Fredo extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Freddie Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mio fratello. Then Bussetta offers his hand back to Fredo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking off his jacket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a trip, Jesus Christ, the whole time I'm thinking what if someone knew what I got in here. He undoes the combination of the briefcase starts taking cash.  Then he stops, remembering that there's a stranger the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, 'scuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.  He stays with me all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Mikey, what's up?  I'm totally in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're making an investment in Havana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, Havana's great.  Lots of activity in Havana!  Anybody I know here.  Five-Angels?  Anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Ola... Hyman Roth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never met them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pentangeli's dead.  He was ambushed by the Rosato Brothers. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, I didn't.  Who tells me anything?  I been kept in the dark so long, I'm getting used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to help me, Fredo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm here for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight I want to relax with you. The Senator from Nevada is here with some people from Washington. I want to show them a good time in Havana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count on me; that's my specialty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to come along.  There's been a lot of strain, and I've been cooped up in this room for three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and you, great!  Gimme an hour to wash my face and do my research and we'll have these Washington suckers right where you want 'em. (then a thought strikes him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Frankie Five-Angels.  He always wanted to die in bed...with a broad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael stands at Roth's door carrying the briefcase that Fredo had brought. A hotel DOCTOR takes Hyman Roth's blood pressure, while h wife waits nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must not exert yourself; I will write out a prescription and come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to write a prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my own doctor; fly him in from Miami.  I don't trust a doctor who can't speak English. The doctor is shown out.  Roth gestures to the hotel man, who also leaves.  Then he looks to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, go down to the casino?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you feel better...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.  Play the Bingo game. They kiss, and she leaves.  Also Bussetta and Ola remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sixth sense tells me you have a bag full of money in your hand. Ola locks the door; Michael nods, and opens the bag, spil its contents on the card table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doubles my investment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still no word of your courier? We'll find him.  But at least this will satisfy our friends here. You've been invited to the New Year reception at the Presidential Home. I understand your brother is here as well; I hope he'll come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six million dollars in cash is a high price for a piece of a country in the middle of a revolution. Roth looks patiently at Michael, as though he were a chil who hadn't minded the lesson that he had been taught over and over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a careful kid, and that's good.  But look.  An international dispatch on the wire service. American journalism, not propaganda. The government troops have all but eliminated the rebels.  All but their radio station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've read it; I'm pleased that the government is doing so well.  As a heavy investor, I'm pleased.  How did the doctor find you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible.  I'd give twice this amount to take a piss without it hurting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who had Frankie Pantangeli killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken a bit off-balance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why...the Rosato Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that; but who gave the go ahead. Roth glances to Ola; he is not a fool; he realizes Michae has begun to suspect him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it wasn't me...so that leaves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was this kid that I grew up with; he was a couple years younger than me, and sort of looked up to me, you know.  We did our first work together, worked our way out of the street.  Things were good and we made the most of it.  During prohibition, we ran molasses up to Canada and made a fortune; your father too.  I guess as much as anyone, I loved him and trusted him. Later on he had an idea to make a city out of a desert stop-over for G.I.'s on the way to the West Coast. That kid's name was Moe Greene, and the city he invented was Las Vegas. This was a great man; a man with vision and guts; and there isn't even a plaque or a signpost or a statue of him in that town.  Someone put a bullet through his eye; no one knows who gave the order.  When I heard about it I wasn't angry.  I knew Moe; I knew he was headstrong, and talking loud, and saying stupid things.  So when he turned up dead, I let it go, and said to myself: this is the business we've chosen. I never asked, who gave the go ahead because it had nothing to do with business. He regards Michael silently a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's three million dollars on that table.  I'm going to lie down, maybe take a nap.  When I wake up, if it's still there, I'll know I have a partner.  If it's gone, then I'll know I don't. The old man turns, and moves in his slippers, toward his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael closes the door, and moves down the hallway.  He followed by Bussetta, who had waited in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How sick do you think the old man is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll live longer than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Havana extravaganza, with tall, beautiful showgirls don up in flamboyant, 'South-of-the-Border' Carmen Miranda costumes; the lead singer is a six foot blonde doing "Rum and Coca Cola" in that style.  Her name is YOLANDA.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: At a large round table, located in an obvious VIP section the high, tropically draped room with living ferns and ot tropical planting with artificial stars. Michael rises, to be introduced by Fredo to some conserva looking Senatorial types, including Senator Pat Geary of Nevada.  We notice Bussetta standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does everyone know everyone, or nobody knows nobody.  Here, my brother, Michael Corleone... well, you know Senator Geary. Geary warmly shakes Michael's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Mike; I'm glad we can spend this time together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Senator Payton from Florida; Judge DeMalco from New York... Senator Ream... Mr. Questadt from California, he's a lawyer with the Price-Control Administration.  And Fred Corngold of U T&T. They all make themselves comfortable.  A waiter with a tr of drinks appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen... your pleasure?  Cuba Libres, Pina Coladas, you name it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a Yolanda. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, later.  All those girls look like they're on stilts! The various tropical drinks are distributed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a night in Havana! They all join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside to Michael)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeeze, it's great you came along, Mike... You know, we've never spent a night out on the town together. I always thought you looked down on me for liking a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never looked down on you, Fredo. You don't look down at a brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the group has made its way into the casino.  Some them are crowded around the crap table; Senator Geary is with the enormous and beautiful Yolanda, who barely speak English.  There are other girls with some of the men; not with Michael, who gambles dollars while talking to Corngo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our information is that Castro is dead.  There are maybe a few hundred die-hards in the Sierra Muestra; but government troops are going to clean them out any day. Johnny Ola approaches Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, can I talk to you. Michael follows Ola toward the Baccarat table; a watchful Bussetta moves, a distance away, with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, this Senator from Florida already has a hundred grand worth of markers on the table. We can see Senator Ream at the table, making thousand dol bets on the Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They asked him to sign paper to take down the markers; but he got mad; told them to wait until he was finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him gamble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  You know he doesn't have that kind of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike said let him gamble. Fredo puts his arm around his brother; he is high with th first attention Mike has ever given him, as though finall he is being taken seriously; as though his brother needs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, I got something special up my sleeve for these boys.  You ever hear of "Superman?" And I don't mean the comic book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait'll you see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our group are in a large Havana bar; the walls totally covered with hundreds of fifths of different types of rum and other liquor. A couple of the girls from the show are out with the men; Yolanda herself is giving them a private song and dance. Fredo is a little loaded, and especially attentive to Michael this night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey, why would they ever hit poor old Frankie Five-Angels?  I loved that ole sonuvabitch.  I remember when he was just a 'button,' when we were kids.  We used to put bedsheets on our heads, you know, like we were ghosts.  An' ole Frankie come peek into our room, we'd jump up, and he'd always pretend like he was really scared. You remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was hard to have him killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?  What do you mean you, I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was hard to have him killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?  What do you mean you, I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Frankie tried to have me hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I mean, are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know otherwise, Freddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?  NO, no, I don't know anything. Fellas!  You're all falling asleep. We got to see Superman.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: A growing feeling about his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is lit with tons of neon signs; it is alive wi people; some roving bands of musicians.  Everywhere are little boys running around, begging for money.  And in doorways and windows are silent, dark-skinned women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing away from the palm outstretched little hands of the boys)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn beggers.  Goddamn city of beggars and pimps and whores.  And we bend over backwards to support them with the goddamn sugar quota.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Geary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's eating him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lost a quarter million dollars at the casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...goddamn city of whores...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave them a bad check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room with a succession of platforms arranged step like around a circular area which becomes a stage. There are a hundred or so people, practically all men, tourists and business men, standing on the different leve forming the audience. In the center of the stage is a thick, telephone type pol to which is tied a young Cuban girl, in a flimsy white sacrificial slip.  A small band, mostly drummers, play so Latin music.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Fredo's party standing on the ramp, looking down at the spectacle.  They're a little woozy from the drinks and la hour.  Michael is with them, but now we sense he is using this time, with all exhausted and drunk, to come to some important conclusions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do we have to stand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stands.  But it's worth it, watch!

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE ARENA
dialogues.text: Now two high priestesses, scantily clad, bring in a tall muscular Cuban, done up in chains and loin cloth, as thou he were a captured slave.  This is SUPERMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him; that's Superman! Some preliminary pornographic proceedings go on, as the priestesses lead the slave to the virgin tied to the post The music is percussive and wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohmygod.  I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got to be fake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they call him Superman. Johnny Ola told me about this; I didn't believe it. CLOSE on Michael turning away.  Not because of the specta which he finds disgusting, but at what his brother is say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but seeing is believing.  Ole Johnny knows all the places.  I tol' you... can you believe it? If Michael would ever allow himself to cry, it would be n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man Roth, would never come; but Johnny knows these places like the back of his hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is alone in his bedroom; it seems as though he hasn't slept very much, but sits by his window, looking o at the city.  He is troubled and tired. His radio is on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "This is Rebel Radio: Rebel troops of Column Four 'Jose Marti' took the town of Baire yesterday at 8:30 p.m.  The enemy has retreated..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This street in Havana is like a Caribbean tourist city wi no indication of the revolution in progress. Michael walks along the street, alone, past the Cubans on their way to work; past the American ladies who have gott up early for their shopping spree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Spanish) (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... An important military action is developing along a 35-kilometer stretch of the Central Highway. Numerous enemy garrisons are left with two alternatives, surrender or annihilation... One full block away, Bussetta rides in the front seat of dark Mercury, driving slowly, giving Michael his privacy, but never letting him out of Bussetta's sight.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: watching.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VIEW
dialogues.text: Shopkeepers happily luring the tourists into their shops broken English.  Havana is prosperous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Victories in war depend on a minimum on weapons and to a maximum on morale...

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: glances back to the dark car following him.  In a moment, pulls up to him, and he gets into the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing by his car, looking through the cyclone fencing that borders this military training camp operated by the American Army near the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... War is not a simple question of rifles, bullets, guns and planes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street singer, followed by a guitarist sings Jose Marti words of "Guantanamera." It is solemn, as though it is a song of protest, a song of the revolution. Nearby, in a restaurant, Michael has lunch with Fredo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your wife, Fredo...your marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her; drives me crazy, one minute she's a popsicle, the next she's all vinegar.  Sometimes I think... I think - I should a married someone, like you did.  To have kids, to have a family. Michael turns, distracted for a moment at something the singer has sung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yo soy un hombre sincero..." I am a sincere man, From the land of the palms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song.  Are you sincere with me, Fredo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sincere.  What are you talking about, of course I'm sincere with you, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm going to confide in you; trust you with something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, are you crazy, I'm your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight we've been invited to a reception at the Presidential Palace; to bring in the New Year. You and I will go in a special car that's being sent.  They'll have cocktails... then dinner, and a reception with the President.  When it's over, it will be suggested that you take Questadt and his friends from Washington to spend the night with some women.  I'll go home alone in the car; and before I reach the hotel, I'll be assassinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same man who tried in Nevada... Hyman Roth, not Pentangeli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, you told me yourself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was never Pentangeli... I've always known that.  It was Roth all along.  He talks to me as a son; as his successor, but the old man thinks he'll live forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To go tonight, with me, as though we know nothing.  I've already made my move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?  Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man will never bring in the New Year. Fredo realizes what he means; looks immediately to Busset who had been sitting near the door and the musicians.  He gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time ever away from Michael, moving toward us quickly.  He stops, knocks on the door of Roth's suite. Then quickly for a man his size, he moves without noise t the adjoining door, opens it with a key, and disappears inside. A moment elapses on the empty corridor, and then a roused Johnny Ola, opens the first door.  He steps out into the corridor, to see who had knocked.  Confused, he is about return inside, when Bussetta easily breaks his neck in tw from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bussetta quietly pulls the limp body of Johnny Ola, hi head bent at an impossible angle, and lays it at the foot the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards who are regular troops patrol the Palace in twos, carrying machine weapons. Now an elite officer, checks the identification of the various cars carrying dignitaries, as they are driven up the Palace.  The one being inspected at the moment contai Fredo and Michael.  We can see the beautifully dressed people on their way to the reception, and sense the cheer mood of this New Year's Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bussetta bends over Ola's body, tying the wrists and knee with electrical extensions.  He then easily carries the b to the small balcony which all the rooms have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bussetta swings the body over the side of the balcony railing; tying the extension cord to the railing, and suspending the body so that it is invisible both from the inside and out during the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRESIDENT, his WIFE and six oldest CHILDREN great formally the many beautifully and affluently dressed gues He speaks to them in Spanish, as one by one they file to Michael and Fredo are presented in a group with several other Americans, including several of the American businessmen with interests in Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The excitement of the night is beginning to build; people are out in the streets; poor people, but they are enthusiastic and lively.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: Traffic stops, as an ambulance speeds its way to a hospit SIREN going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bussetta delicately picks up a small satin cushion that h fallen from the couch, and replaces it as though nothing happened.  Slowly he cracks the door open which adjoins Roth's bedroom.  There is a slight commotion; whispered voices.

dialogues.speaker: BUSSETTA'S VIEW
dialogues.text: Terri, Mrs. Roth, is crying.  A group of men lift Hyman Roth's frail body onto a stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: BUSSETTA
dialogues.text: realizes that this is the man he is to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is alive; breathing hard with his mouth dry and open. The doctor examines him, and then gives instructions to t orderly who carries him out, presumably to the ambulance. Bussetta closes the door on this VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orchestra plays for the guests, as an army of waiters serve champagne and hors d'oeuvres.  Michael relaxes with Senator Geary, Major Leon, and several of the Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The embargo on arms shipments from the U.S. to your government, was just a necessary public relations move... Only last month, your air force received a major shipment of rockets... Michael glances at his watch; Fredo concentrates on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe in non-intervention... but the agreement stipulates that our forces may be withdrawn... but as you've seen, we have not withdrawn them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my guess is that President Eisenhower won't pull out while we have over three billion invested over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo.  Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowhere, Mike.  I wanted to get a refill.  How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance makes its way up to the emergency section o the hospital.  The orderlies quickly carry the old man inside.  His wife and the doctor, and several of his men, follow in another car.

dialogues.speaker: THE VIEW ALTERS
dialogues.text: and we see Bussetta waiting in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The growing crowds of Cubans begin their celebration.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: A Cuban military detachment speeds along in the night, motorcyclists clear a path through the celebrants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full sitdown dinner is being served the guests.  Michae sits at a table at dinner with several of the distinguish Cubans, and some of the American businessmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's kept Mr. Roth? Fredo looks up at Michael. In the back of the room, we notice the detachment of mili moving quickly through the reception room on their way to the President's private quarters.  Michael notices it as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The activity at the end of the hall has come to rest; we tell that the doctor tells Mrs. Roth that she should go, old man will be taken to a room where he can rest. Gradually, these people leave him in the care of the hosp staff. Bussetta watches from the distance of the hallway; after old man has been moved, he quietly walks down the hallway the room.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: A nurse sits in the room in attendance; Hyman Roth is asleep, his mouth wide open, breathing noisily.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON BUSSETTA
dialogues.text: hears footsteps, quickly steps away from the door, and in another room. Some nurses and attendants speak to the nurse in the room Spanish; one has brought a small bottle of wine, and obviously they are inviting the nurse to have a New Year' toast with them.  They laugh; and the nurse steps away fr the room for a moment. Bussetta moves slowly back into the room, alone with the helpless Roth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seeing in the New Year; a great banner is hoisted up in Spanish, welcoming 1959. Hands are shaken; kisses exchanged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Fredo in an embrace; they kiss one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've arranged for a plane; we're going to Miami in an hour.  Try not to make a big thing of it. He kisses his brother once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was you, Fredo.  You've broken my heart. Slowly, understanding, Fredo backs away from his brother, taking the kiss another way. A little distance away, Major Leon notices an old woman, of the President's maids, moving across the alcove, carry her suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a pity; she's crying.  Must have been fired, and she's been with the President's family for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gathered crowd joyously welcomes the New Year.  We notice the continual military movement.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: A family surreptitiously leaves their home, carrying suitcases and belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bussetta raises a hospital pillow, and easily begins to smother the thin old man, who can barely struggle.

dialogues.speaker: OUT IN THE HALL
dialogues.text: A detachment of military move quickly, accompanied by som of Roth's men, as though they have important news that mu be dealt with. They pass the small group of aides and nurses welcoming t New Year. Seeing them, the nurse assigned to him, puts down her gla and moves quickly to the room. She opens the door, and lays bare the sight of Bussetta smothering Roth.  Bussetta turns quickly; and one of the military takes out his pistol and shoots several times at his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire reception has been disrupted for an announceme all the guests in their formal dress and evening gowns, standing with frightened faces like first class passenger on a doomed ship.  The President himself, his back to our VIEW, is making an announcement in Spanish.  While he speaks, we notice continuous movement of his personal sta carrying suitcases and possessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Because of serious setbacks of our troops in Guantanamo and Santiago, we feel reluctantly, that we must leave the Capital at once. Myself and my family must bid you goodbye, and good fortune.  We will go directly to Ciudad Trujillo. The crowd is stunned; already whispers are moving through the guests. The only one who is not completely taken off guard is Michael, who quietly steps back, and disappears from the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My only regret is that there could not have been more warning... As my last official act as President, I hereby appoint a provisional government with Dr. Carlos M. Piedra, as its President. By now, there is only one thought among the guests: how c they get out, and with what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see evidence of the confusion at this late hour; alrea cars are beginning to move; people leaving the Palace in haste.  Michael moves quickly toward his car.  He sees Fredo, watching him in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.  It's your only way of getting out!

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON FREDO
dialogues.text: Terrified of his brother, and what he knows; Fredo backs away into the growing noise and confusion of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Finally, he has to step into the car and it roars off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebel cars with loudspeakers have already picked up the n that Batista has conceded...this throws the crowds alread gathered for the New Year into cheers of joy. They harass a wealthy family who are trying to get away i their car. The people pull them out of the car, opening their suitca out of which spill piles of cash and jewelry into street. Michael's car makes its way as the crowd cheers: "El anim se fue!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowds of panicked and frightened tourists, and Batistian are trying to get to the safety of the Embassy with the families and possessions. We see Geary, and some of the Americans we had met, worki their way through the crowds, shouting that they are Americans in order to get preference on the line.  Often that declaration brings 'boos' from the crowds. Sometimes the joyous Cubans will let a family through, bu again, taking away the suitcases, rich leather, filled wi money and valuables.  Money seems to be stuffed everywher

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All forms of private transportation are jammed with peopl trying to get out, holding cash in their hands for anyone with a yacht or small boat to get them to Florida. A car pulls up; and we see Sam Roth, Terri Roth and some their men, carry the sickly, but still alive Hyman Roth t private cruiser which is protected by men with machine gu Within seconds, they are on their way to Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are no different at the airport; where anything th can fly is being jammed with refugees and their money. A wealthy family is arguing with the pilot of a fast airplane; trying to force cash on him, and his family int the plane.  The PILOT steadfastly refuses, although check his watch, as though his passengers are late.  He speaks only English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is a private plane.  No, this plane is taken. Finally Michael's Mercury pulls up, and Michael approache the Pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to leave, they'll take this thing apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Go now. The Pilot lets Michael in, as the Cuban screams curses at them, and begins searching for another plane for his fami

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the propeller turns over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groups of the cheering, celebrating Cubans sing "Guantanamera," now as a song of triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer to him, his personal and business life caught in t middle of history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops to pick out some choice oranges and peaches from fruit stand.  Then he reaches into his pocket for change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  It is my pleasure to make this a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are kind.  If ever I can do something for you, in return, please come to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite his new position of 'respect,' there is little changed about his home.  Only that they have lived there while now, and the rooms are fuller with the inevitable possessions a young family acquires. He kisses his wife, who seems a big apprehensive.  He sho her the fruit; and from her reaction knows she has someth on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come... They step into the tiny parlor, where we see an older wom waiting nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Signora is a friend of mine. She has a favor to ask of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you come to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me to ask you. He seems surprised; looks to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is having some trouble.  Her landlord has received complaints because of her dog.  He told her to get rid of it, but her boy loved it, so they tried to hide it.  When the landlord found out, he was so angry, he ordered her to leave. Even if she truly will let the dog go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he would have the police put us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you some money to help you move, is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends are all here; how can I move to another neighborhood with strangers?  I want you to speak to the landlord to let me stay. Vito nods to the frightened old woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's done then.  You won't have to move; I'll speak to him tomorrow morning. Carmella breaks into a smile; which her husband des not acknowledge. The old woman starts to leave the room; but she is not convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure he'll say yes, the landlord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he's a good-hearted fellow. Once I explain how things are with you, I'm sure he'll take pity on your misfortunes.  Don't let it trouble you any more. (as he shows her out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guard your health, for the sake of your children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIGNOR ROBERTO, a pompous, rather well-dressed Patrone angrily walks down the steps of one of his tenement build He carries a check list, and makes marks with a pencil concerning the condition of his various buildings; a brok window here, some missing tile there.  He bends over to p up some garbage left by a thoughtless tenant, muttering t himself, when he sees the shoes and legs of a young worke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signore Roberto... He rises to be face to face with a polite Vito Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The friend of my wife, a poor widow with no man to protect her, tells me that for some reason she has been ordered to move from your building.  She is in despair.  She has no money, she has no friends except those that live here. Signor Roberto brusquely answers, and continues on his wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have already rented the apartment to another family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her I would speak to you, that you are a reasonable man who acted out of some misunderstanding. She has gotten rid of the animal that caused all the trouble, so why shouldn't she stay.  As one Italian to another, I ask you the favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already rented it; I cannot disappoint the new tenants.  They're paying a higher rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much more a month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh... (we sense he is lying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five dollars more. Vito reaches into his pocket, and takes out a roll of bil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is the six month's increase in advance.  You needn't speak to her about it, she's a proud woman.  See me again in another six months. But of course, you'll let her keep her dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell!  And who the hell are you to give me orders.  Watch your manners or you'll be on your Sicilian ass in the street there. Vito raises his hands in surprise; his voice is reasonabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking you a favor, only that. One never knows when one might need a friend, isn't that true?  Here, take this money as a sign of my good-will, and make your own decision.  I won't quarrel with it. (he puts the money in Roberto's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me this little favor, just take it and think carefully.  Tomorrow morning if you want to give me the money back, by all means do so.  If you want the woman out of your house, how can I stop you?  It's your property, after all.  If you don't want the dog in there, I can understand.  I dislike dogs myself. (he pats Roberto on the shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me this service, eh?  I won't forget it.  Ask your friends in this neighborhood about me, they'll tell you I'm a man who believes in showing his gratitude. Without a word more, Vito leaves a hypnotized Roberto standing in front of the tenement, his hand clasping the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin young man, almost gawky, walks down the street in this Italian neighborhood, his name is HYMAN SUCHOWSKY. He carries his tools as he comes home from work.  He is pursued and tormented by a couple of Italian youths, abou his own age, eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get those nigger lips? He tries not to be intimidated; finally one of the boys, steps in front of him and stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say 'bread' in Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on; how do you say 'bread' in Italian?  If you're from the neighborhood, you should know how to say 'bread' in Italian. An amused Peter Clemenza steps forward from a local coffe house, to preside over the fuss.  He's a 'big' man in the neighborhood, and loves a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kid lives around here, but he can't say bread in Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's 'cause he's Jew.  Look at those pregnant lips! He giggles at his own joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a Jewboy? The boy doesn't answer, tries to keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're not a Jew, say 'bread' in Italian.  See, he can't. And with that, he rounds a blow squarely to the boy's fac sending him sprawling to the cement, his tools flying wit clatter. The other Italian immediately joins in with a few kicks t the boy's stomach.  Hyman tries to fight back; grabs a ho of his tormentor's foot, and brings him down on the cemen as well.  For a moment, they are rolling around on the sidewalk, two against one, Hyman taking the worst of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright, cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?  He killed Jesus Christ! Clemenza pulls him off, and kicks him in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said cut it out! (to the beaten kid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyman Suchowsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.  In our neighborhood, with a name like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those tools?  You work on cars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I know how you can make a couple of extra bucks working as a mechanic. The boy seems agreeable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you gotta know how to keep your mouth shut, and fer Chrissakes, get rid of that name.  I'll call you Johnny Lips. (he giggles at his own humor again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... He leads the boy down the street, whispering to him, on t side:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bread in Italian is pane.  P-A-N-E, pane.  Don't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A newly acquired warehouse, stocked with cases of the new product "GENCO PURA" olive oil.  It is the beginning of a new business, in the American tradition.  Now they have o rattling old truck, and a few stock boys. Genco has become the accountant-business manager, based o the experience working with his father.  But it is clear, that Vito is the leader, and undisputed 'President' of th new enterprise. Genco moves through the darkness of the warehouse, to the small divided area that Vito uses as his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'patrone' is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberto.  Who owns the 'rat-holes.' Vito nods that he will see him; and soon Roberto enters, tiptoe, his hat in his hand, and in a apologetic voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I hope I am not a disturbance, Don Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a terrible misunderstanding. Of course, Signora Colombo can stay in the flat.  Who were those miserable tenants to complain about noise from a poor animal...when they pay such low rent. Then abruptly, he puts the roll of money on Vito's table, and steps back a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your good heart in helping the poor widow has shamed me, and I want to show that I, too, have some Christian charity.  Her rent will remain what it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, reduced, bu five dollars! Vito embraces him warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I accept your generosity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't keep you another minute... He quickly takes his leave, bowing several times, and the makes it back to the safety of the warehouse; he sighs, deflates his lungs, and mops his brow; his bones have tur too jelly with fear at his narrow escape.  He all but run out of the warehouse. Genco laughs as he watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't see him for weeks!  He'll stay in bed in the Bronx! Clemenza has been waiting with his new mechanic.  We noti the subtle difference in the way he treats Vito.  He is n longer a junior apprentice in their petty crimes; but an imposing leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kid is good with cars; he kiijed at the truck, and says he can keep it going. Vito looks over the lanky young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suchowsky.  Hyman Suchowsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna dump that; I call him Johnny Lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is the greatest man you can think of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, answer him when he talks to you.  Tell him: Columbus, Marconi... Garibaldi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arnold Rothstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take that as your name: Hyman Rothstein. Genco is out in the alley; he calls out with glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitone!  Look at this! Vito moves out to the smiling Genco; Clemenza and the new christened Hyman Rothstein follow a distance behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genco stands beaming, as two workers raise up high, the freshly painted sign: "GENCO OLIVE OIL COMPANY."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless America!  We're in business! The young men watch as the sign is hoisted into place.  O VIEW goes from one to the other: Clemenza, Genco, Vito an Hyman Rothstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy Cicci, Pentangeli's associate and bodyguard takes a drink of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cicci.  From the year 1927 to the present time, you were an employee of the "Genco Olive Oil Company."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in actuality, you were a member of the Corleone Crime organization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corleone Family, Senator.  We called it, "The Family."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What position did you occupy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, like everybody, I was a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON SENATOR KANE
dialogues.text: A thin, angular Baptist with a Mid-Western accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A button.  You know, Senator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't know, explain that exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the boss says push the button on a guy, I push the button, see, Senator? The Senators treat Cicci with a surface courtesy, as if h were a curious kind of animal, not really human.  Cicci reacts to this by being even more brutally forthright tha he has to be, to show his contempt for what he considers hypocrisy. The VIEW ALTERS from Senator Kane to the Committee's attorney, Mr. Questadt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you killed people at the behest of your superiors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, counsellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the head of your family was Michael Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, counsellor, Michael Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever get such an order directly from Michael Corleone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Senator, I never talked to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very autocratic, deep South, gentlemanly man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was always a buffer, someone in between you who gave you orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a buffer, the Family had a lot of buffers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A limousine pulls up at a private area near the side of t hotel.  Michael exits the limousine followed by Hagen and Neri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think they have somebody to back up Cicci?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But if they do have somebody, you'll do three years for perjury if you give them so much as a wrong middle name. Michael smiles to him, but it's a cold, deadly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, take the Fifth all the way, that way you can't get into trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Corleone bodyguard waits outside on the balcony overloo the pool area.  Through the translucent draperies, we see grouping of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, Hagen, Neri and Rocco are seated in this luxury the hotel.  Michael sits in a comfortable chair in his apartment.  Neri comes and brings him a drink without asking, but Michael refuses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al, get me a wet towel.  Does Kay know I'm back? Hagen nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the boy get something from me for Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it, so I'll know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little care he can ride in with an electric motor. Neri comes around with a wet face towel, which Michael us to cool his eyes.  He puts the used towel down on the tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas, can you wait outside a minute? They know what he means and leave the apartment, going ou to the balcony where we can see them but they cannot hear Only Hagen remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roth got out on a private boat. He's in a hospital in Miami.  Had a stroke but he's recovered okay. Bussetta's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked about Fredo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new government arrested him, held him for a couple of days with a lot of the other casino people, including Roth's brother, Sam.  The American Embassy arranged flights for citizens; I'm not sure, but I think he's somewhere in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to reach Fredo.  I know he's scared, but have one of our people reach him.  Assure him that there will be no reprisals.  Tell him that I know Roth misled him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My information is that Fredo thought it was a kidnapping.  Roth assured him nothing would happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Rocco and Neri on the balcony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can come in now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... there's something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Hagen pauses; doesn't know how to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay had a miscarriage; she lost the baby. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, at three and a half...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, can't you give me straight answers anymore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Kay...she's all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took the Senate Investigation worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she blame it on me?  The baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first snow of the New Year has fallen; the trees are bare, and there is hush all over this part of the Sierras Michael is driven in his car, looking out at the familiar sight of the home he has been forced to be away from.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: looking out from his window.  The last time he had seen t estate it was warm, and the trees were full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: approaching the great stone gates; closed.  The bodyguard are not readily visible, but they are there.  The iron ga are opened, and one of the men makes a simple nod of resp as the car pulls in.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: Inside the estate, the private roads have been freshly plowed, and occasionally a worker will pause to watch the car as it passes. The Grandchildren are in school now, and so the estate is especially quiet.  Although there are signs that children live here; a bicycle, a sled, a swing and gymnastic set, and with a rim of snow still on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to the outside, where Michael walks slowly.  He stops and looks at a little Italian red sportscar made for children

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: The front door opens, and Michael enters his own home.  I is very quiet, no one is at home to greet him.  He can se the evidence of his family; things his wife and his child have been using, and left on a sofa or a table. He moves toward his and Kay's bedroom, where we can HEAR SOUND of a sewing machine running. Quietly he opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VIEW
dialogues.text: into the bedroom.  Kay is sitting by the window, lit by t cold afternoon light, at work with her sewing machine.  S hasn't noticed that he's in the room yet, and goes on wit her work.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: stands there a moment, watching, not making a sound.  And then without a word, he steps back, and closes the door, that she doesn't see him.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW FROM INSIDE THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: onto Michael, moving outside, walking through the snow, h moves to the house next to his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the house where Mama lives with Connie's children Connie so rarely is there. He steps in; his mother is asleep in a chair in the livin room.  He moves to her, and bends low, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom... Mom... She opens her eyes, which are red and small with age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Michael.  How are you, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm alright.  Will you stay home for awhile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are still things I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can all have a nice dinner together tonight.  How are your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  They bother me once in awhile. (a pause as he thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, when Pop had troubles... did he ever think, even to himself, that he had gone the wrong way; that maybe by trying to be strong and trying to protect his family, that he could... that he could... lose it instead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk about the baby.  She can have another baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I meant lose his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as best she ever understood it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family?  How can you ever lose your family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But times are different...

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW IN ROOM
dialogues.text: Quietly we HEAR the music of a small band playing an Ital march.  From the orchestration, we know it is from the pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitone and his young family: Mama, Santino, Fredo and the baby Michael are met at the small station in Sicily by friends, and Mama's relatives.  There is a small band, playing for the occasion.  A small man has brought a moto car to pick the family up; and there are certain dark men with shotguns slung over their shoulders to preside over occasion. The family is helped into the car; the luggage is packed the roof, and the car drives off.  The second car, with bodyguards following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The villa is bloomed with flowers and DON TOMASINO at thi point is a man in his late twenties.  He embraces Vitone pats the heads of his children, and leads them all into t garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sumptuous table is set for the visiting family from America.  There is a warm atmosphere as Vito, his wife an children eat.  Tomasino and his family received presents from Carmella and to Tomasino's mother, and gifts are giv to all of the children. All typically American representing some of the prosperit and interests in the consumer goods that followed a great

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family exits the church on the plaza of the town.  Vi shakes hands warmly with the priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is open -- the footsteps of a man enter the room We follow these footsteps without quite knowing to whom t belong.  They lead us to a bed, where we see asleep an OL MAN.  He sleeps in his undershirt and is sweating, covere by mosquito netting.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ALTERS
dialogues.text: and we realize that it is young Vito looking at the MAN. We remember that the man is MOSCA, one of three men, who almost twenty years before had hunted down Vito when he w a boy.  With lightning speed, Vito slashes through the mosquito netting with a knife.  And with the movement precise as a butcher's he disembowls this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito has brought his wife and children to see the Olive O Depot which is the link to his New York importing busines They go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are led by one of Vito's associates through rows and rows of large vats of olive oil.  Vito very proudly shows his associates in Italy the olive oil can that will be us in the United States.  They all stand around at the link their new importing business and share a toast of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A team of Sicilian fisherman are at work mending their ne One sings accompanied by a guitar.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW MOVES TO ONE OF THE OLD FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: He is recognized as the second of the men who had hunted Vito down.  STROLLO.  As he walks we notice there is a figure that is moving through the drying sails and barrel it is Vito.  He moves quietly, stepping up behind the old man.  In an instant, he has thrown a garrote around his throat, twisting it tight, so that there is very little sound. Then, almost silently dragging him through the space hidd by the drying sails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an old car approach.  Its driver is the young Toma Sitting in the car with him is Vito. The car stops at the gates, and an old guard sees and recognizes Tomasino, opens the gates allowing them to ent

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: on an almost decrepit DON FRANCESCO.  He must be in his early nineties, sitting as powerful and as impressive as ever, in his throne-like chair from which he manages the power as the Mafia Chieftan of this village.  Young Don Tomasino is speaking. We notice in a little distance in the rear, there are som younger shepherds with shotguns thrown over their shoulde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Francesco, if you will honor me, by allowing me to introduce my associate in America, in New York. His name is Vito Corleone. The old man and his eyes glance up at a notion of a man w has taken the name of this town as his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will supply him with olive oil exclusively in the town of Corleone. His company is called the "Genco Olive Oil Company." Here we have brought you an indication of how he will sell the product. Tomasino respectfully puts a can of olive oil where the o man can look at it.  The old man nods, accepting the noti of this business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have come to ask your blessing and permission to continue this enterprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian) (in a shrill, high, raspy voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is this young man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is right here, standing next to me, Don Francesco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have him come closer, I can't see very well. Vito takes those several steps, so that he is standing ri in front of the old man.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON DON FRANCESCO
dialogues.text: looking up, squinting against the sun.

dialogues.speaker: DON FRANCESCO'S VIEW
dialogues.text: Strangely backlit, almost blurry image of the young man f America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vito Corleone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took the name of this town, eh? What was your father's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antonio Andolini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The recognition of the name throws a shudder through him. It is as though he recognizes that this is the boy; the s of his old enemy, whom he had killed, and whose sons he h tried to wipe out.  The old man raises his feeble hands signalling his guard, and in his weak voice, he shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him!  Kill him! But he is too late; Vito steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sicilian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of my Father, and my Brother... And uses the knife, ritualistically plunging it into the man's belly, and then up to his throat, which is severed.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON TOMASINO
dialogues.text: has drawn his pistol and quickly shoots one of the guards helping Vito to escape back into the motor car.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON A GUARD
dialogues.text: raising his shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE MOTOR CAR
dialogues.text: Just as Tomasino is about to get into the car, the shotgu is fired, and he is hit in the legs. Vito manages to pull him up into the car, and they make their escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the townspeople have come bringing flowers and gi for Vito and his family. His wife is radiant with the flowers given her. The train has arrived and the crowd shout "Ciao, come bac soon."

dialogues.speaker: THE VIEW ALTERS
dialogues.text: revealing his good friend Tomasino, waving from his wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON VITO
dialogues.text: and his wife.  She holds up the baby Michael, and helps h wave his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the son of Vito Corleone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he use at times an alias?  Was this alias in certain circles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was not an alias.  GODFATHER was a term of affection, used by his friends, one of respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Senator from New York, very smooth, partly liberal, Tammany Hall)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me agree with that.  Many of my constituents are Italian and have been honored with that certain friendship by my close Italian friends.  Up to this point before I have to leave this hearing to join my own committee, let me say, that this hearing on the Mafia is in no way a slur on the Italians by the Senate; nor is it meant to be; nor will I allow it to be.  Italian Americans are the hardest working, most law abiding patriotic Americans of our country.  It is a shame and a pity that a few rotten apples give them a bad name.  We are here to weed those rotten apples out of the vast healthy barrel of Italian Americans, who are one of the backbones of our country. There is a pause for a while, while the New York Senator poses for the TV cameras and leaves the hearing so that h will not be associated with hearing the rough stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we all agree with our esteemed colleague.  Now, Mr. Corleone, you have been advised as to your legal rights.  We have had testimony from a preceding witness who states you are head of the most powerful Mafia family in this country.  Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This witness has testified that you are personally responsible for the murder of a New York Police Captain in the year 1947 and with him a man named Virgil Sollozzo.  Do you deny this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deny his every charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true that in the year 1950 you devised the murder of the heads of the Five Families in New York, to assume and consolidate your nefarious power?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a complete falsehood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true that you own a controlling interest in three of the major hotels in Las Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not true.  I own some stock in some of the hotels, but only very small amounts.  I also own some American Telephone and IBM stock. Michael had checked this point with Hagen, before answeri and then once again after the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it necessary for your counsel to advise you on that question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator, I've observed the head of General Motors before a Senate Committee, and his lawyer whispered in his ear.  That was not commented upon in the way you have just done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Corleone, do you have any hotel interests in the state of Arizona? Or any gambling interests in that state?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have interests or control over gambling and narcotics in the state of New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not. A pause.  Silence, as the Chairman whispers something to assistant. Tom Hagen takes a paper out of his briefcase, and address the Chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator, my client would like to read a statement for the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, my client has answered every question asked by this committee with the utmost cooperation and sincerity.  He has not taken that Fifth Amendment as it was his right to do, and which because of the extreme legal complexity of this hearing, counsel advised him to do. So, I think in all fairness this committee should hear his statement and put it in the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
