dialogues.text: Very well. At this point Senator Rogers contemptuously walks out of hearing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hopes of clearing my family name, in the sincere desire to give my children their fair share of the American way of life without a blemish on their name and background I have appeared before this committee and given it all the cooperation in my power.  I consider my being called before this committee an act of prejudice to all Americans of Italian extraction. I consider it a great dishonor to me personally to have to deny that I am a criminal.  I wish to have the following noted for the record. That I served my country faithfully and honorably in World War II and was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross for actions in defense of my country.  That I have never been arrested or indicted for any crime whatsoever... that no proof linking me to any criminal conspiracy, whether it is called Mafia or Cosa Nostra or whatever other name you wish to give, has ever been made public.  Only one man has made charges against me, and that man is known to be a murderer, arsonist and rapist.  And yet this committee had used this person to besmirch my name.  My personal protest can only be made to the people of this country.  I can only thank God that in this country we have a legal system and courts of law to protect innocent people from wild accusation.  I thank God for our democratic due process of Law that shields me from the false charges made by this committee's witness.  I have not taken refuge behind the Fifth Amendment, though counsel advised me to do so.  I challenge this committee to produce any witness or evidence against me, and if they do not, I hope they will have the decency to clear my name with the same publicity with which they have now besmirched it.  I ask this without malice, in the interests of fair play. The television cameras have documented this moment, as Ha hands the document over to the committee lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all impressed.  The committee will now recess over the weekend. However, it will continue Monday morning, at eleven a.m.  At that time, this committee will then produce a witness directly linking Mr. Corleone to the charges we have made.  And then, Mr. Corleone may very well by liable for indictments of perjury.  However, this document will be made a matter of record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An army post somewhere in the East.  It is safely guarded

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where Pentangeli is being held by his constant companions the two FBI MEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten to one shot, you said.  Ten to one shot in my favor, and I lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a good night's sleep.  We got a new suit, new shirt, new tie, and I'm going to shave you myself. Tomorrow we want you to look respectable for fifty million of your fellow Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life won't be worth a nickel after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a special home for you for the rest of your life.  Nobody gets near you.  You're not going any place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, some deal I made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live like a king.  You'll be a hero.  You'll live better in here than most people on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some deal. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wish Mike had took the Fifth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you do it, Frankie?  After all these years, why'd you turn against him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't turn against nobody; he turned against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A somewhat frightened Fredo Corleone sits in the easy cha overlooking the lake in this canopied section of the boathouse.  Rocco sits with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is in the dark room with Hagen and Neri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did they get their hands on Pentangeli?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roth engineered it, Michael.  He made Pentangeli think you hit him. Deliberately letting him get off alive.  Then the New York detectives turned Frankie over to the FBI.  My informants say he was half dead and scared stiff -- talking out loud that you had turned on him and tried to kill him.  Anyway, they had him on possession, dealing in heroin, murder one and a lot more. There's no way we can get to him and you've opened yourself to five points of perjury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got him airtight.  He's in a military base, twenty-four hour guards.  Trying to kill him is like trying to like the President -- it's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does Fredo know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he doesn't know anything, and I believe him.  Roth played this one beautifully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  I'm going to go outside and talk to Fredo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo sits on the couch.  When Rocco sees Michael, he automatically takes his leave.  Michael sits in the chair opposite Fredo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a lot to say, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was kept pretty much in the dark. I didn't know all that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about now, is there anything you can help me out with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know they get Pentangeli, that's all I know. Fredo gets up, walks to the glass panel that separates th terrace from the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know it was a hit.  I swear to you I didn't know.  Johnny Ola contacted me in Beverly Hills -- said he wanted to talk.  He said you and Roth were in on some big deal, and there was a place for me in it if I could help them out. They said you were being tough on the negotiation, and if they had a little bit of help, they could close it fast and it would be good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you believed that story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said there was something good in it for me...me on my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always taken care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taken care of me.  Mike, you're my kid brother, and you take care of my.  Did you ever think of that. Ever once?  Send Fredo off to do this, send Fredo to take care of that... take care of some little unimportant night club here, and there; pick somebody up at the airport.  Mike, I'm your older brother; I was stepped over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the way Pop wanted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't the way I wanted it!  I can handle things.  I'm not dumb Christ, not like everyone says. I'm smart; and I want respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing more you can tell me about this investigation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lawyer; Questadt, he belongs to Roth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're nothing to me now, Fredo; not a brother, not a friend, I don't want to know you, or what happens to you.  I don't want to see you at the hotels, or near my home.  When you visit our Mother, I want to know a day in advance, so I won't be there.  Do you understand? Michael turns, and starts to leave.  A frightened voice behind him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey? Michael doesn't stop, doesn't turn back.  He continues of through the veranda, and out the summer doors. Neri stops by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want anything to happen to him while my Mother's alive. Michael leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five cars brimming with Army guards and Agents are waitin to move Pentangeli.  There is one empty car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two FBI Agents are helping Pentangeli get dressed.  H in brightly colored striped shorts and bare-chested.  The Agents help him with the shirt and tie.  One holds out th trousers but Pentangeli ignores it and looks at himself i the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. The Agents open the door, and precede him, surveying the area.  They check the cars waiting, each with two Agents. They check the gate and note the military sentries.  Then they stand aside, and let Pentangeli come out.  They get close to his side, and it is obvious they will protect hi life with their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Agents put him in the front seat of the empty car, an get in with him, one at each side.  Another Agent drives. Now, the first cars start out; the Sentries opening the gates, and letting the caravan pass. An Army supply truck comes very close to them, and the Agents next to Pentangeli become very tense.  Pentangeli grins.  Then the truck passes on, and they relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is crowded with TV journalists, cameras, etc.  W pick Pentangeli up, closely guarded, being led to witness chair. Pentangeli is seated, and made to take his oath.  FBI Age are all around him.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Anyone given entrance to the caucus room is being frisked The five Senators take their places.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN
dialogues.text: waiting at his long table, very nervous.  He seems startl by the appearance of Pentangeli.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON PENTANGELI
dialogues.text: catching Hagen's eye.  It's as though he is pleading for some kind of understanding of the fact that he has become traitor.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN
dialogues.text: cold; then he turns away.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: The bustle is settling down; then Michael Corleone enters and with him is someone very peculiar and out of keeping this setting.  A burly-chested imposing man of middle age Very powerful-looking with frightening magnetic eyes.  Hi dress is odd: boots, rough tie, and shirt.  He could be t tenor out of a Sicilian opera.  He is clearly a country D direct from Sicily, and he dominates the room.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON PENTANGELI
dialogues.text: At first his view is blocked.  Then he sees Michael and i bit shamefaced, but still defiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael returns his glances without emotion.  Then the VI ALTERS, revealing the Sicilian.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON PENTANGELI
dialogues.text: He is terror stricken; obviously he recognizes the man.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON HAGEN'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Michael and the Sicilian sit by Hagen, where they can sta directly at Pentangeli; he is frozen with fear.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE SENATOR
dialogues.text: Notices the tension in the room.  The Chairman commences:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have here a witness who will testify further on Michael Corleone's rule of the criminal empire that controls gambling in this country and perhaps in other countries.  This witness had no buffer between himself and Michael Corleone.  He can corroborate our charges on enough counts for this committee to consider a charge of perjury against Michael Corleone. (then he turns to Pentangeli)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name please, for the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Pentangeli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you a member of the Corleone Family?  Were you under the Caporegime Peter Clemenza, under Vito Corleone, known as the Godfather? There is a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON PENTANGELI
dialogues.text: He seems unable to speak.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE SICILIAN
dialogues.text: gazing at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never knew no Godfather.  I got my own family. Senator Kane is stunned.  The two FBI men are alert, thei eyes searching the room for what has intimidated their witness at the last moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pentangeli, you are contradicting your confessions to our investigators; I ask you again, were you a member of a crime organization headed by Michael Corleone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I never heard of it.  I never heard of nothing like that.  I was in the olive oil business with his father a long time ago.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have your confession that you murdered on the orders of Michael Corleone.  Do you deny that confession and do you know what denying that confession will mean to you? The die is cast and like a good soldier, Pentangeli will all the way now.  So he is brazen in his defiance of the Senator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FBI guys promised me a deal. So I made up a lot of stuff about Michael Corleone.  Because then, that's what they wanted.  But it was all lies.  Everything.  They said Michael Corleone did this, Michael Corleone did that.  So I said, "Yeah, sure." He makes a big grin to show how he has made fools of everybody.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE FBI AGENTS
dialogues.text: glancing around the room; their eyes have settled on the Sicilian.  One of them scribbles a note on a piece of pap and passes it to the Committee lawyer.  Then in turn it g to Senator Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hagen, would you kindly identify to this committee that gentleman sitting on your right hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  His name is Vincenzo Pentangeli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he related to the witness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is, I believe, a brother.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL AND VINCENZO PENTANGELI
dialogues.text: They wait with no expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vincenzo Pentangeli)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I would like you to take the stand. Vincenzo stares at him, uncomprehending.  There may just a shadow of contempt.  He doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the gentleman does not understand English.  He would not in any case, take the stand.  He came, at his own expense, to aid his brother in his trouble.  He is not under any jurisdiction of our government and his reputation in his own country is impeccable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The witness is excused; take him out. The guards and FBI Agents quickly remove Pentangeli, as everybody else in the room is required to sit still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This meeting is adjourned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising and shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This committee owes an apology!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee is adjourned until further notice. For the first time, in the midst of the confusion, Hagen smiles.  A bitter, contemptuous smile.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The modest champion.  He rises and they take their leave.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE TWO FBI AGENTS
dialogues.text: They watch the Corleone party as they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corleone nurse is waiting, playing with the little gi MARY.  A distance away, the boy, Anthony, is standing by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to Michael's suite opens; Rocco leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Kay. Michael is sitting in an easy chair; he seems to have difficulty with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she's here. Michael rises, surprised.  Rocco steps back, and Kay ente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to see you before you went back to Nevada.  Also, the children - Michael, they're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute.  They're outside with Esther.  I'm very happy for you... I suppose I knew that you're simply too smart for anyone ever to beat you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to stay long; I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a lot of things I want to talk to you about.  Things I've been thinking about -- changes I want to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's too late for changes, Michael.  I promised myself I wouldn't talk about it and I've gone and spoiled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why too late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Michael.  What really happened with Pentangeli?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His brother came to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even know he had a brother. And where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a plane back to Sicily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's all he had to do.  Just show his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.  You see, in Sicily, in the old days... there was only one legitimate reason to kill a blood relative... only one.  IF he was a traitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would have killed his brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, you've got it wrong.  That kind of thing's all over, I promised you.  This was between the two brothers.  Years ago Frankie had a young girlfriend; he called her his co-wife.  That was his joke, but he meant it.  He wouldn't divorce his wife... because she was a great cook.  He said he girlfriend made a spaghetti sauce once and it was so terrible he knew he could never marry her.  He set her up in a house in Jersey.  She had to be faithful... and she had to have kids. And she did, two, a boy and a girl. He had her checked out and watched so she couldn't cheat... but the girl couldn't stand that kind of life.  She begged him to let her go. He did.  He gave her money and made her give up the kids.  Then Frankie took them to Italy, and had them brought up by his brother Vincenzo. Where he knew they'd by safe. Kay begins to realize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he saw his brother in the hearing room, he knew what was at stake. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Vincenzo would have done it.  He loves the kids, too. Omerta, Kay.  Honor, silence.  It had nothing to do with me.  It was between those brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring the children up now; they want to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, I told you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't let you leave!  Christ, do you think I'm going to let you leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meekly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want to hear anything. There are things between men and women that will not change; things that have been the same for thousands of years.  You are my wife, and they are my children... and I love you and I will not let you leave, because you are MINE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I do feel things for you, Michael; but now, I think it's pity. For the first time since I've known you, you seem so helpless.  You held me a prisoner once; will you try again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's what it takes; then yes, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, I feel no love for you at all.  I never thought that could happen, but it has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go back tonight.  Bring the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't heard me. He moves to her; he does love her, and is tender with her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I let you leave; how can I let you take my children away? Don't you know me?  You understand, it's an impossibility.  I would never let it happen; no, never, not if it took all my strength, all my cunning.  But in time, soon, you'll feel differently.  You see, you'll be happy that I stopped you.  I know you.  You'll forget about this; you'll forget about the baby we lost... and we'll go on, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby I lost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it meant... and I'm prepared to make it up to you.  I will make changes; I can. (he clenches his fist tightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I CAN change; that I have learned, that I have the strength to change... And we have another child, a boy... and you'll forget the miscarriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a miscarriage.  And you with your cunning, couldn't you figure it out!  It was an abortion; an abortion, like our marriage is an abortion, something unholy and evil.  I don't want your son; I wouldn't bring another of your sons into this world.  An abortion, Michael... it was a son, and I had it killed, but this must all end!

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: He had no hint, not in his wildest imagination could he h guessed that she would do such a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know that now it's over; I knew it then, there would be no way you could ever forgive me, not with this Sicilian thing that goes back two thousand years. He is silent, though raging -- then, with all his passion and his strength, he raises his arms, and strikes her acr her neck, literally knocking her down to the floor, and hurting her badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't take my children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A collection of dark cars and black limousines are gather to one side.  A few drivers wait quietly. And then, to the other extreme of the estate, is a small grouping of about twenty to thirty people, gathered near Michael's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie Corleone, dressed simply and now showing her age without the carefully applied makeup which we have been u to, kneels down before the shrine of Santa Theresa, and p down a bouquet of flowers, along with others that have be placed there.  We see that some have the simple silk ribb with the word "Mama" hand-lettered upon it. Her two children stand close behind her; they had been raised by their Grandmother. Connie steps back, and moves through the small group of friends and relatives, into Michael's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo, kneeling by the coffin of his mother in a portion the house that has been set aside for the wake.  Fredo concludes his prayer, wipes away the tears in his eyes an steps away from the coffin. He stops when he notices Neri, a little distance away, looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON NERI
dialogues.text: After a moment, he nods respectfully to Fredo, and steps forward, moving to the old woman's coffin.  Fredo moves t Hagen, who is there with his wife and children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom.  Where's Mike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (difficult to tell him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waiting for you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No chance.  I'm sorry, Freddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has heard this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael sits quietly in the darkened room in one of the b sofas, dressed immaculately in suit and tie.  His two children, also dressed for the wake sit opposite him in t other oversized sofa, their shoes not touching the floor. We regard this tableau for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael?  It's Connie. She comes in, and sits down by his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to stay close to home now, is that alright? Michael nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Kay coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, Fredo's in the house with Mama.  He asked for you, and Tom said he couldn't see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids, why don't you go outside for a while? The children don't move; Connie realizes they will only listen to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children can stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated you for so long, Michael; for so many years.  I think I did things to myself, to hurt myself, so that you would know -- and you would be hurt too.  But I understand you now; I think I do.  You were being strong for all of us, like Papa was.  And I forgive you, and want to be close to you now.  Can't you forgive Fredo; he's so sweet, and helpless without you. Slowly, Michael puts his hand on her hair, and touches he gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need me, Michael.  I want to be with you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends, relatives; Francesca and her new husband, Gardne and their baby; Sandra Corleone; Teresa, her children; al the familiar faces of the family are present, quietly pay their respects to Mama. Some of the men can be seen in the kitchen, drinking wine and talking in low voices. Fredo is there, broken-hearted over the loss of his Mothe like some lost child with no friends.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Michael enters the room, followed by Connie, who tends little Mary and Anthony. He approaches his brother, and then embraces.  Fredo brea into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Mike.  Jesus Christ, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: embracing his brother, he glances up.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON NERI
dialogues.text: quiet, and deadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Hagen is talking in the distance to his wife, and one his older sons; he kisses, and moves toward the boathouse After crossing the lawn, he stops.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON SANDRA CORLEONE
dialogues.text: waiting there; obviously wanting to talk to him.  He continues, and she walks with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they cross toward the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to talk to him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. She stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, think of yourself for once. Don't let this opportunity slip through your fingers; don't do it. We're all trapped here, don't you see? He continues past her, without answering her.  Continues to the boathouse.  He stops before he enters.

dialogues.speaker: HAGEN'S VIEW
dialogues.text: Fredo is sitting by the edge of the harbor with Michael's son Anthony; he is helping him with some fishing rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking through the window at his son and brother.  Neri sits in the room, dressed informally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Tom.  Have you heard about our friend and partner, Mr. Hyman Roth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he's in Israel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands Hagen the paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The High Court of Israel turned down his request to live as a 'returned Jew.' His passport's been invalidated except for return to the U.S.  He landed in Buenos Aires yesterday, offered a gift of one million dollars if they would give him citizenship.  They turned him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to try Panama...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't take him; not for a million, not for ten million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His medical condition is reported as... "terminal."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been dying of the same heart attack for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That plane goes to Miami...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want it met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, it's impossible.  He'll be met by the Internal Revenue; the Customs Service, and half the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it when you use the word impossible; nothing is impossible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, it would be like trying to kill the President; there's no way we can get to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised at you, Tom.  If there's anything certain; certain in life; if history has taught us anything, it's that you can kill... (he stops, then coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANYBODY.  But perhaps your relucatance is because you've come to tell me that you're moving your family to Vegas, that you've been offered the Vice-Presidency of the Houstan Hotels there.  Or weren't you going to tell me at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you so hungry for traitors; do you want to find them everywhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I turned Houstan down; I didn't see why I should tell you about an offer I turned down. (Michael begins to confuse him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure, Mikey?  Are you sure of what we're doing; what we'll gain; what does the family gain? Forget that, Mike; I already know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do, Tom.  Then I can count on you to help me do the things I have to do.  If not, call Houstan, and become a Vice-President. Take your family and your mistress and move them to Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you hurt me, Michael?  I've always been loyal to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Then you're staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying. (he pauses...then, without being asked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever enjoy the cruel part of all this; Sonny never listened to me about that. (then he sits down, and opens his briefcase)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, explain everything to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo sits with Anthony, with a silly-looking fishing hat his head, covered with lure and flies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, ole buddy, your Uncle Fredo's gonna teach you how to catch the big fish.  You know, when I was a kid, I did this amazing thing.  I went out on a fishing trip; me and my brothers and my Pop, and no one could catch a fish except me.  And this was my secret: (confidentially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I would put the line down I would say a "Hail Mary" and every time I said a "Hail Mary" I would catch a fish.  Now, when it's sunset, we're gonna go out on the lake, and we're gonna try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards step aside as Tom Hagen enters the foyer of th house.  He shows a court order to them and they lead him the stairs where he knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK at the door.  The two guards show Hagen and Hagen presents the court order to one of the FBI men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I prefer to see my client privately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has a bug in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the FBI men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to go outside with him, in the open air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This room is not bugged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have guards outside and the electric fence.  There's no security reason for not letting us talk in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. They pass out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagen and Pentangeli outside, by the electric fence.  The cannot be overheard.  Pentangeli takes out some cigars an offers Hagen one.  Hagen takes it and Pentangeli lights b their cigars.  They puff on them contentedly.  They are comfortable together, almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is going to be okay, Frankie, don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my brother go back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's ten times tougher than me, my brother.  He's old-fashioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  He wouldn't even go out to dinner.  Just wanted to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my brother.  Nothing could get him away from that two mule town.  He coulda been big over here -- he could of had his own Family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, what do I do now? The light is beginning to turn reddish as the sun falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie, you were always interested in politics, in history.  I remember you talking about Hitler back in '43.  We were young then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I still read a lot.  They bring me stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were around the old timers who dreamed up how the Families should be organized, how they based it on the old Roman Legions, and called them 'Regimes'... with the 'Capos' and 'Soldiers,' and it worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it worked.  Those were great old days.  We was like the Roman Empire.  The Corleone family was like the Roman Empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was once. They both puff on their cigars.  Pentangeli lets himself carried away by thoughts of old days of glory; Hagen thin of other days too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Roman Empire... when a plot against the Emperor failed, the plotters were always given a chance to let their families keep their fortunes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but only the rich guys.  The little guys got knocked off.  If they got arrested and executed, all their estate went to the Emperor. If they just went home and killed themselves, up front, nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was a good break.  A nice deal. Pentangeli looks at Hagen; he understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They went home and sat in a hot bath and opened their veins, and bled to death.  Sometimes they gave a little party before they did it. Hagen throws away his cigar.  Pentangeli puffs on his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about anything, Frankie Five-Angels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Tom.  Thanks. They shake hands.  The FBI Agents come out to let Hagen o the gate.  Pentangeli is led back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lawyer tell you he can get that 600 years reduced to 500? Pentangeli puffs on his cigar and reflects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys sure you can't get me a broad for tonight?  Give me a little party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got some nice books. Pentangeli puffs on his cigar and gives the Agent a smile old man gives a child.  He starts upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll just take a hot bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagen walks away; glances back.  Then gets into his waiti car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael sits alone in the empty boathouse; in the shadows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neri stands by the dock area under the boathouse.  He pus the button which lowers a boat by winch and tackle.  He wears a fishing cap. He steps into the boat, and pulls the small outboard, whi glides the boat out into the harbor.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The boat pulls up alongside Fredo and Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go; and remember the secret. He lifts Anthony into the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR VIEW
dialogues.text: Connie, in houseclothes, is calling Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here; we're goin' fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't go; Michael wants to take him into Reno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.  Okay, kid, you got to go to Reno with your Pop. He lifts the boy out of the boat, and puts him on the sho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll catch one for you, with the secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, Anthony. Neri stands the motor; and the boat with the two fisherma glides off.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: watching, from the dark window of the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FBI man knocks on the bathroom door in the house wher they have kept Pentangeli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie, open up.  You okay? No answer; he hammers on the door.  Using his elbow, and then a kick he breaks into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: Pentangeli lying in a tub of water.  His stomach shows ab it.  His wrists are cut and covered with blood.  The bath water has a purplish tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fredo and Neri are fishing, each with lines out.  The VIE MOVES CLOSER, and we can hear Fredo as he holds the pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the Lord is with thee.  Blessed art thou amongst women, and blessed is the fruit of thy womb, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat on the shimmery lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Holy Mary, Mother of God, pray for us... We hear a quiet, echoing GUNSHOT; and then silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exhausted Hyman Roth, ill-shaven, and in shirt-sleeves taken into custody by a swarm of Customs, and FBI men.  T allow him to be photographed by press people; and televis cameramen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roth, we have to take you into custody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. Some flashbulbs go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you give us your reaction to the High Court of Israel's ruling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a retired investor on a pension, and I wished to live there as a Jew  in the twilight of my life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roth is not a well man; he's tired of running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an old man; at my age, it's too late to start worrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true you are worth over three hundred million dollars, Mr. Roth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a retired investor, living on a pension... I came home to vote in the Presidential election, because they wouldn't give me an absentee ballot... The newsmen and photographers all laugh, as the FBI men m him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the newspapermen laughing we recognize to be Rocco Lampone. He moves closer to Roth, and shoves his revolver right against his head, and in a second, on camera, assassinate Roth.  People scream, as Rocco attempts to run down the airport corridor, limping as he does. FBI men easily pick him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi cab waits by the house; its driver sleeping with a newspaper over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cleaning woman, Esther, who had been with Kay for yea sits by the dining room table, weeping profusely.  Behind her, in the recreation room, we can see the tableau of Ka sitting on the couch, her little daughter Mary, between h knees, talking quietly about things we cannot hear.  Her Anthony sits by himself, in another chair by the side of room.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Connie comes into the house quickly, and moves toward the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, you have to go. This prompts Esther to weep all the more.  Kay hugs her daughter, and kisses her many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to hurry; he's coming. Kay puts her coat on; then stands, and reaches out for he son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, kiss Mama goodbye. He doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, you kiss your Mother goodbye! He rises, and walks to her.  Hugs her lifelessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on Kay, kissing her boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, say goodbye; your Mama loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. She restrains any tears; she has become too strong for te Kay starts to go; picks up Mary, kisses her, and starts t

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: She steps out the kitchen door; then she cannot help hers Crouches down, outside, and calls to her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, kiss me once. Then she looks up, and slowly rises.

dialogues.speaker: HER VIEW
dialogues.text: Michael has stepped into the dining room.  He seems older somehow; as though some sickness has taken more years awa from him.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KAY
dialogues.text: looks at him; instinctively, she takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: slowly steps toward her.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KAY
dialogues.text: Another step back; the door is still open.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: He moves closer to the door; stops, looks at her.  And th closes it obscuring any view of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late fall -- most of the leaves have fallen on the grounds and there is quite a wind.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The water is whipped up by the wind, and the waves are hi as they break against the pavilion.  We HEAR the MUSIC of time passing, of Michael, of the Godfather over these ima

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE SWIMMING POOLS
dialogues.text: They have not been used in several months; they are drain and the bottoms are mossy and dark.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE MAIN GATE
dialogues.text: Leaves blowing past it; we don't see the button men; only hint of someone in the gatehouse.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE HOUSES
dialogues.text: Some of the houses have had the summer awnings taken down and put away.  Some of the windows have been boarded up.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE KENNELS
dialogues.text: There are still the guard dogs; some sleeping, some movin impatiently. As the MUSIC concludes its statement.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The peninsula of the private Corleone Harbor.  We see the figures of two people, seated at a table.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Michael sits at a table having a sparse lunch.  He is attended by his sister Connie, who seems to be the closes person now living on the estate with him.  We see from th way she pampers him with his lunch, that she has fallen i the role of a surrogate Mother-Wife.  He seems older than his years, as though his illness, diabetes, has taken its toll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry; I'm sure he got here on time.  The roads from the airport are so windy, it takes forever; I've driven them myself. She picks up some of the serving plates that he has left untouched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring him out to you as soon as he comes. She moves back to the main house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and looks at the rough water of the lake for a moment.  He slowly takes a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a few chairs.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW ON ANTHONY CORLEONE
dialogues.text: He is eighteen years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: squinting up at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony. He rises, and reaches up to his son, who is now taller th he; he embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've grown so tall... so tall in the last year.  You're much taller than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was taller than you when I was fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.  Your Aunt Connie and I waited for you to have some lunch, but now it's all dried out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's alright... alright. Good.  You'll graduate in another year, isn't that right?  You know... I never finished college.  I was a good student, but I never finished. Of course, there was a war then. Connie approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let me interrupt anything, this will just take a second.  Here. (she takes out a small needle, and begins to prepare it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father has to have his insulin shot.  Why don't you go to your room and put your things away, Anthony. She begins to give Michael the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry back; we'll talk.  We'll talk. Anthony goes on his way to the house with his things. Connie gives Michael the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever I see that lake so cold, I think of poor Fredo, drowned.  Lake Tahoe is very cold.  They say if a person drowns in it, that the body will remain mid-suspended -- perfectly preserved.  Some say it will remain forever. She finishes the shot, puts her things away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boy will be right back. She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Alone in the garden. OUR VIEW begins to MOVE CLOSER to him.  We begin to HEAR MUSIC of the forties; happy music, swing music, as we mov CLOSER to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONNY CORLEONE, his arm wrapped around a smiling red-face Carlo Rizzi, pulls him into the Corleone dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, who knows my buddy Carlo Rizzi. Here... my brother Fredo, here's my Mom.  Mom, whatcha got cooking? And Carlo, this is my kid sister Connie.  Here, pull up a chair, Carol is sitting next to Connie. Oh, the droopy kid over there is Mike.  The college boy. An older, lanky man enters the room, his arms laden with presents.  This is TESSIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon Natale, everybody.  Buon Natale... (he smiles at Tom Hagen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Tom, how's every little thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping him with the presents)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful, Sal. Now the study door opens, and DON CORLEONE enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is dinner ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes. The Don happily regards his family; his sons and daughter and even some Grandchildren.  He raises a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good life, a long life to all my children, and friends.  To my grandchildren, and those that will be.  To our family. They all drink. They refill glasses; then Tessio proposes a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To our Godfather. They all drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is happily at Christmas dinner.  Don Corleone seated at the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you think of those Japs, eh? The nerve of those Japs, coming right here in our own backyard dropping bombs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we could have expected it after the embargo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Expect it or not, those Japs don't have a right to drop bombs in our backyard.  Whose side you on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, do we have to talk about the war at the table?  On Christmas, much less.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: He has been listening to this discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, I've decided I'm going to enlist. A quiet hush descends over the table, as though everyone knows the effect this will have on the old man.  Sonny tr to make light of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, stay in college.  The girls are cuter, if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop had to pull a lot of strings to get you your deferment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never asked for it; I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON DON CORLEONE
dialogues.text: Disturbed; but wise and prudent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son wants to talk about this, and so we'll talk, but not at the dinner table. He rises, and starts across the room toward his study.  T he looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael. He disappears into his study.  Michael rises, glances aro People are generally tense over the situation.  Michael follows his father into the study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Don closes the door behind his son, and then moves across the room.  He stops at the little bar there, and pours himself a brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what is this talk about joining the army?  Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not talk; I'm doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would risk your life for strangers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for strangers; for my country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone not in your family, is a stranger.  Believe me, when trouble comes, your country won't take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how it was in the old world, Pop, but this is not Sicily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I know, Michael.  It's Christmas, your brothers and sister are all here -- we are happy. Let's not spoil this.  Go your own way, but when you are ready, come to me the way a son should.  I have hopes for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking at his father with a mixture of great love, and a fear, and confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be a man like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leaves are blowing.  MUSIC comes up. Michael and his young son, Anthony, walk through the grou of the estate, talking about things we cannot hear.
